story:
OUR MISSION

Articollectiva was created to showcase art in all its forms to the world. We curate and create pop-up, impromptu exhibits showcasing the most avant-garde, though-provoking, and beautiful work from emerging and established artists of all pedigrees. We work with painting, drawing, sculpture, spoken word, the performing arts, and even move beyond those parameters. We believe art is an expression where intellect, creativity, and imagination come together and materialize into universal communication. 

We believe the artist and the audience matter the most. Art is a creative human endeavor where our personal genius is given room to shine. The majority of people do not get the chance to experience and enjoy this genius. They rarely get the opportunity to become a part of this genius either. Articollectiva's purpose is to change that. 

Below are a few of the essentials that make up the Articollectiva DNA. They are the universal truths that drive us to create and share with the world:

  1. Art belongs to the world.
  2. Art is Universal expression.
  3. Art is the most human language of communication.
  4. Art is subjective and meant to be admired in a person's own time and space.
  5. Artists and their work have an unquestionable right to be admired.
  6. We are all creative beings with artistic potential as we deem fit.

FOUNDER


I am Lillian Moya, the founder of Articollectiva. My background is in the arts and began by using fine point black ink Pilot pens and white copy paper. I then decided I wanted to go to art school.

While still in school I was given the chance to exhibit in NYC, Chelsea, and also Miami. I was invited to exhibit internationally with Carlos Mata, an Internationally renowned Cuban artist, but that was an impossibility. I found that being an artist was beautiful AND so difficult. There was so much talent amongst us, and so much of it was being unnoticed because we just did not have the means to connect to the right people or the right places.

So what did I find happens a lot of the time when art gets overlooked? When talent gets overlooked? Sometimes we find jobs in other industries. Sometimes, like I did, we go back to school to study something remotely "stable". I studied business. So now I work a lot, and have absolutely no time to work on anything creative.

Why does talent need to be overlooked? Why does the artist need to jump so many hurdles? Why can't we live in a world where art is supported by the same people who happen to buy art for their own pleasure? Articollectiva is not about creating a Utopian society where we can all sit back and paint, draw, act, sing. Why would we want to live in a world like that? Why would we want to live in a world where we don't have access to the pleasures the arts can bring us? 

My goal, my greatest goal, with Articollectiva, is to allow art to shine. To bring talent back to the world. So, we don't want to b glued to our smartphones all the time. Or TV sets. Well, then lets help art happen! Art exists all around us, and we all love it in one way or another, whether we see it as art or not. Articollectiva is trying to shape the world so you have access to all of it. 

You may want to call us disruptive, and essentially that may be exactly what we are. We are helping artists take back their world. What I mean by that is that too many hurdles need to be jumped to have your work exhibited, lets say. Too many times some recognition is post-humous. Many times, more than any other circumstance, amazing work, whether in painting, book, song, or the stage gets overlooked. It never gets noticed. So yes... we are disrupting what very few people have had access to for decades now, and making it available to the masses. We cannot do that without these events. This is why we need your help. 


THE ARTICOLLECTIVA GROWTH CAMPAIGN

This story is why I founded Articollectiva. I found myself in a corner, and no matter how much I tried I still had almost nowhere to go. This campaign is solely for the purpose of helping Articollectiva move from it's hometown of Miami, Florida, to other cities where we can showcase amazing work by amazing artists of all kinds, and help bring art back to the world. Art is not about a sole convention once a year that many people cannot go to. It's not only about what we hear a piece sold for in a city we have never been to. 

Art is experience. Art has the power to make you feel. It has the power to make you see, realize, think, do. Art does not only need to be on a canvas. It can be a beautiful chair, it can be a one-person dance where they express freedom and transfer that same feeling to the audience. Art can be a word that changes your life. Art can be anything. And art really is everything as long as we can see it. 

Articollectiva is about art. It's about people. It's about all of us. That is what this growth campaign is about. It's about bringing those experiences, in any form we can find them, to the world. We will not be able to do it without you. You are a part of this experience too, and we need you to collaborate with us in the making of this art. 

OUR WORK


We are focused on removing the barriers between artist and audience. Visualizing and materializing experience to relish in the joys of life. Emerging and mid-career artists are the future we want to help create as we experience, admire, and help collect their work. 

Virgo || Constellation Series (acrylic and high gloss on canvas)

Make Me Believe You (acrylic and high gloss on canvas)

Andromeda || Constellation Series (acrylic & high gloss on canvas)

FORWARD THINKING

Innovation, disruption, and beauty is our view of the Universe. These are a few of the exhibits the future holds:

  1. Collectiva Relevance
  2. The Art of Simplicity
  3. Extravagant Rubbish & Empowerment 
  4. Junkyard Rhetoric
  5. For the Love of Dreams

WHERE OUR INSPIRATION COMES FROM


Articollectiva was founded in Miami, and is traveling all corners of the world because art is in everything we see and everything we do. A young city has evolved and changed into a metropolitan conglomerate with the power to reach and influence every part of the world in every language. We call Miami home because like Miami, Articollectiva is a worldly, human endeavor meant for the world to enjoy and participate in. 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU'LL GET

Here are a few of the most important details to this campaign:

  • Our goal is to raise $50,000. This is all going towards creating events. This is a purely a growth campaign. Art exhibits. Renting a playhouse. Giving you perks for your help. It's the beginning, and we need your help to get things started. 
  • Some of the perks we are offering include originally signed and dedicated screenprints of Internationally renowned artists, thank you's, lifetime partnership ads on our website, and more!
  • If we do not reach our goal the funds will still go towards growing Articollectiva, although it will need to be in a smaller scale. We will possibly need to move more slowly. Maybe rent smaller spaces. Maybe even offer different raffle prizes at the end of every event. The operational goal of the campaign does not change regardless of the monetary goal not being met. We are completely focused and determined to make Articollectiva the collective that empowers artists. 

THE IMPACT YOU WILL MAKE

Articollectiva is an artist's collective created by artists, and because too many artists, and too much art, is overlooked. Whether we are in the wrong city, or know the wrong people, we want to give everyone that wants to create, and show their work, the chance to do so. That barrier that exists where artist and audience rarely come together, even if it's only with the piece causing the connection needs to be broken. The establishment that is art is one that is meant to be free of those barriers. People want to see art. They want to experience it. They want to become a part of it. Your contributions will help make this happen. 


We curate pop-up exhibits. We work with artists and they work with us to make this happen. We do not have a gallery space. The purpose is to bring art to all of us. And for all of us to be in this art. 


  • Art does not live in a vacuum. We each deserve to be inspired, to see and feel beauty. To experience wonder. This is our goal. To bring this to you. 
  • We inaugurated in 2015, in the Wynwood Art District in Miami. The show was a success. And everyone who exhibited and those in the audience loved the fusion of what Articollectiva offered them. The night was about the art and the audience's experience. It was about the artist. We simply helped put it together. Now we need your help to do it again, in other cities, and bring art back to life. Back to us.  
  • Artists are the original innovators. They are the original disruptors of the world. They inspire. They dream. They create. And we are all a part of it. Without the world, every person in the world, Articollectiva would not exist. Our philosophy is based on the world. On the connections between us all, that help create magical moments, that sometimes get materialized into a representation to be shared with the remainder of those who were not there that first time - they are there now. We need you. We would not exist without you. 


SOME OF THE RISKS WE FACE & BENEFITS

  • People stop making art.
  • People stop wanting art.
  • The world becomes saturated with Articollectivas and we have too much competition to grab anyone's attention. 
  • We are trilingual, so we can communicate in English, Spanish, and French. Luckily those languages are helpful, but we are extremely open to working and collaborating with others all around the world. Articollectiva is a global endeavor. It is a change we feel is necessary to bring some color back into our lives.
  • We are young, and just starting out, so we are eager to grow and evolve along with the world and those whom we work with. We are only set in the way of enjoying the beauty life has to share. In every other way we re ready to adapt for a more positive future.
  • We believe in those we work with, and want them to believe in us. The desire is endless, and we feel the need is abundant. That makes this an immense priority for us. 
  • This is the world we all belong to, and that being said, it matters a lot. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP


If you can't contribute to Articollectiva, we want to thank you regardless and consider some of these ways to remember and help us:

  • Spread the word out about Articollectiva's Growth Campaign.
  • Go to our website, and lets start talking on the forums!
  • Help us grow by spreading the word via Social Media. 
  • Send us an email via the site. Tell us about yourself. Share your thoughts. We want to hear from you!
  • Have an idea? Let's do it! Send us an email so we can schedule a chat! 
  • It doesn't matter where you are in the world, lets connect. We're a human community. 


Thank You So Much! We appreciate you just for being you. You're awesome! We hope to be in contact with you again soon!
story_txt:
OUR MISSION

Articollectiva was created to showcase art in all its forms to the world. We curate and create pop-up, impromptu exhibits showcasing the most avant-garde, though-provoking, and beautiful work from emerging and established artists of all pedigrees. We work with painting, drawing, sculpture, spoken word, the performing arts, and even move beyond those parameters. We believe art is an expression where intellect, creativity, and imagination come together and materialize into universal communication. 
We believe the artist and the audience matter the most. Art is a creative human endeavor where our personal genius is given room to shine. The majority of people do not get the chance to experience and enjoy this genius. They rarely get the opportunity to become a part of this genius either. Articollectiva's purpose is to change that. 
Below are a few of the essentials that make up the Articollectiva DNA. They are the universal truths that drive us to create and share with the world:


Art belongs to the world.
Art is Universal expression.
Art is the most human language of communication.
Art is subjective and meant to be admired in a person's own time and space.
Artists and their work have an unquestionable right to be admired.
We are all creative beings with artistic potential as we deem fit.


FOUNDER


I am Lillian Moya, the founder of Articollectiva. My background is in the arts and began by using fine point black ink Pilot pens and white copy paper. I then decided I wanted to go to art school.


While still in school I was given the chance to exhibit in NYC, Chelsea, and also Miami. I was invited to exhibit internationally with Carlos Mata, an Internationally renowned Cuban artist, but that was an impossibility. I found that being an artist was beautiful AND so difficult. There was so much talent amongst us, and so much of it was being unnoticed because we just did not have the means to connect to the right people or the right places.

Sometimes, like I did, we go back to school to study something remotely "stable". I studied business. So now I work a lot, and have absolutely no time to work on anything creative.

Why can't we live in a world where art is supported by the same people who happen to buy art for their own pleasure? Articollectiva is not about creating a Utopian society where we can all sit back and paint, draw, act, sing. Why would we want to live in a world like that? Why would we want to live in a world where we don't have access to the pleasures the arts can bring us? 

My goal, my greatest goal, with Articollectiva, is to allow art to shine. To bring talent back to the world. So, we don't want to b glued to our smartphones all the time. Or TV sets. Well, then lets help art happen! Art exists all around us, and we all love it in one way or another, whether we see it as art or not. Articollectiva is trying to shape the world so you have access to all of it. 

You may want to call us disruptive, and essentially that may be exactly what we are. We are helping artists take back their world. What I mean by that is that too many hurdles need to be jumped to have your work exhibited, lets say. Too many times some recognition is post-humous. Many times, more than any other circumstance, amazing work, whether in painting, book, song, or the stage gets overlooked. It never gets noticed. So yes... we are disrupting what very few people have had access to for decades now, and making it available to the masses. We cannot do that without these events. This is why we need your help. 


THE ARTICOLLECTIVA GROWTH CAMPAIGN
This story is why I founded Articollectiva. I found myself in a corner, and no matter how much I tried I still had almost nowhere to go. This campaign is solely for the purpose of helping Articollectiva move from it's hometown of Miami, Florida, to other cities where we can showcase amazing work by amazing artists of all kinds, and help bring art back to the world. Art is not about a sole convention once a year that many people cannot go to. It's not only about what we hear a piece sold for in a city we have never been to. 

Art is experience. Art has the power to make you feel. It has the power to make you see, realize, think, do. Art does not only need to be on a canvas. It can be a beautiful chair, it can be a one-person dance where they express freedom and transfer that same feeling to the audience. Art can be a word that changes your life. Art can be anything. And art really is everything as long as we can see it. 

Articollectiva is about art. It's about people. It's about all of us. That is what this growth campaign is about. It's about bringing those experiences, in any form we can find them, to the world. We will not be able to do it without you. You are a part of this experience too, and we need you to collaborate with us in the making of this art. 


OUR WORK




We are focused on removing the barriers between artist and audience. Visualizing and materializing experience to relish in the joys of life. Emerging and mid-career artists are the future we want to help create as we experience, admire, and help collect their work. 



Virgo || Constellation Series (acrylic and high gloss on canvas)


Make Me Believe You (acrylic and high gloss on canvas)


Andromeda || Constellation Series (acrylic & high gloss on canvas)

FORWARD THINKING
Innovation, disruption, and beauty is our view of the Universe. These are a few of the exhibits the future holds:



Collectiva Relevance
The Art of Simplicity
Extravagant Rubbish & Empowerment 
Junkyard Rhetoric
For the Love of Dreams

story:
Who are we and what we do


Marina ready for Kridhanala dance; Marina and Tea performing Saman dance; Tea and Marina ready for Indonesia; Tea performing Pendet dance

Selamat siang everyone! We are Marina and Tea from Croatia and we would like to present our project about picture scroll theatre – wayang beber – on the Indonesian island of Java. During our study visits to Central Java we both became enthusiastic about this type of wayang theatre and started writing down and documenting our experiences and this research continued even after we got back home. Being cultural anthropologists and new admirers of this art, our curiosity soon developed into a research project. Based on the research we've done to date, we concluded that wayang beber has not been given the attention it deserves. Considering that most of the written documentation is in the Indonesian language and the documents in English are outdated, we want to contribute with new research discoveries that present the current state of wayang beber tradition. Additionally, we want to create audiovisual documentation of this unique artistic tradition in order to capture what would be lost with written descriptions alone.

THE NEXT STEP IN OUR PROJECT is to go back to Central and East Java this summer and conduct our field research!

Since this type of theatre combines many different artistic forms (music, painting, audio-visual arts, singing, acting and storytelling), this has inspired us to observe it and learn about it from different viewpoints and by collaborating with local artists. Even though it is already defined as a dying art form, the qualities of wayang beber (both in form and the philosophy behind it) still keep on inspiring Javanese artists that are passionate about creating contemporary wayang beber performances. This is why we believe that it is important to document the old and the new forms of wayang beber and we need your help!

History and modernity in wayang beber theatre


What we have and what we still need

We are happy to say that our project has been recognized as worthy of support by the University of Oxford (Institute of Social and Cultural Anthropology: Philip Bagby fund - Small research travel grant), which will partially cover our travel expenses. Also, we received the Beasiswa Unggulan Research Scholarship from the Indonesian Ministry of Education and Culture, which will cover most of our fieldwork expenses and the second part of travel expenses. Hooray!

However, there are two things we still need funds for:

1/ Technical equipment

Since one of the project aims is to create audiovisual documentation of traditional and contemporary wayang beber theatre, we need good equipment for that!

What we have now                                                  What we need

= 1.750 USD (photo camera, lens, additional battery, extra memory card)

After this project, the technical equipment will stay in the NGO's property and will be used for many other projects that we have in plan!

2/ Accommodation

We plan to rent a small house for the two of us, for a period of 3 months in Yogyakarta. That will cost us 250 USD in total! (3 x Rp 1.000.000 = Rp 3.000.000 = cca 250 USD)

TOTAL COST: 2.000,00 USD

Every contribution is of great importance for reaching our goal, which we’ve tried to keep modest and realistic. In case we raise more money than the current goal, we will use it for our exhibition in the Ethnographic museum at the beginning of 2017 (printing photographs, creating scenography, etc).


What we give in return


Whatever your contribution, it will be greatly appreciated! Here are sample pictures of the possible perks we offer:

WAYANG KULIT PUPPETS

RAMA AND SINTA SMALL SET                 WAYANG KULIT PUPPET (LARGE)* 

 

                                             

*Photos are an example of wayang puppets available online; the puppet characters would be chosen according to your preferences and availability.

UNIQUE BATIK SHIRT CUSTOM MADE FOR YOU*

 

*Photos are an example of custom made batik clothing from Solo available online; details would be arranged according to your preferences and availability.


COTTON BAG WITH A PRINT OF YOUR CHOICE

 


A POSTCARD FROM JAVA

Bromo                                                    Karimunjawa islands


Other ways you can help

If you are not in a position to contribute financially, there are other ways you can help us:

-  SPREAD THE WORD! Share this campaign with your social networks, family, friends, and everyone you think might be interested in our project!

-  If you are in Zagreb/Croatia - help us set up the exhibition in January 2017! We appreciate enthusiastic and skillful people, so feel free to contact us!

-  If you speak Indonesian/Javanese - help us translate interviews!

-  Send us your comments and suggestions on how to improve - we are always happy to hear constructive criticism!


Your impact

By supporting our research, you will help us create a database about this extraordinary cultural and artistic practice for future generations. We want written and audiovisual documentation about wayang beber to be available to everyone, especially because it is seen as a dying art form. We believe that the way this old and almost forgotten Javanese theatre influenced the contemporary art scene on Java is a great example of revitalizing intangible cultural heritage. Therefore, it can be seen as a positive model of revitalization that can inspire others to be creative in exploring and promoting their own heritage. Your contributions will also help support these artists to continue their wonderful work and provide us all with enjoyment as we watch history and the present come together in a uniquely Javanese way.


Timeline

A short summary of what & when!


Contact: wayangbeberproject@gmail.com


Project coordinator:

http://angart.org/en/


Supporters and media coverage:

      

 

  


In media (only in Croatian):

Travel web site "Putoholičari"

Travel web site "HRbackpacker"

Exhibition "Javanese pavilion" in Sisak:

https://wayangbeberproject.wordpress.com/2015/12/13/izlozba-javanski-paviljon-u-sisku/ 

http://sisakportal.hr/izlozba-javanski-paviljon/

https://www.facebook.com/events/810645905719198/

http://www.sisak.info/izlozba-javanski-paviljon-u-galeriji-sv-kvirin/

http://www.domkkv.hr/izlozba-javanski-paviljon-u-galeriji-sv-kvirin/

http://www.sisakturist.com/hr/kalendar/pregled/otvorenje-izlozbe-javanski-paviljon/160


Documentary film about making of a gong "Making of Slendro Limo" by Tea Škrinjarić

JAHORINA film festival, Bosnia and Herzegovina 2015

CRAFT in FOCUS festival, The Netherlands 2015

FIFEQ, Canada 2016

ETHNOCINECA film festival, Austria 2016


Za hrvatsku verziju preuzmi PDF!

story:
REMEMBER TO CLICK ON THE PERKS BEFORE PAYING GUYS!


Introduction/About:

We are a group of college students that love Pokemon gen 4. This year marks the 10th anniversary for Pokemon Diamond and Pearl, and as super devoted Sinnoh fans, we really want to do something special for the anniversary. We decided a zine would be a great way to accomplish this. This is a non profit project; All donations will go to the production of the fan zine!  

As we mentioned before, we are college students and we are broke, so donations will be very VERY appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

We really need you to donate because:

  • We cannot afford to print out every copy for every participants in the project alone.
  • We want to include more artists/writers, and we can barely afford to include the artists/writers we have now. 
  • All donation goes to the production of the zine, we do not profit.
  • We want to spread the love for gen 4 and including every gen 4 lovers!
We have many different perks, based on different tiers you will get:
  • Keychain
  • Buttons
  • Post card(s)
  • Stickers
  • Legal size print
  • Art prints that will not included in the final book and will not be available in the preorder
  • The physical copy of the zine
  • The more funds we get the more perks we can add!

The Impact

WIth you contribution, we can:

  • Get more artists/writers to join the project
  • That will result in more pages and content in the end product for every reader!
  • Make more bonuses for buyers
  • Spread the love for Sinnoh

Risks & Challenges

Money is our biggest issue; if we don't have enough funds we cannot include as many artists/writers as we would like and cannot print out enough copies.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!! Tell your friends about this project!!

story:
FandomWares "Our Artists Fit You"


One day I wanted to know how I could play with the big boys and so I asked my WeLoveFine sales rep about getting exclusive rights to shirts. Shortly after this discussion, I saw JadedJynx’s Warrior Dash print and said to myself that would be an amazing shirt. I then contacted the amazing JadedJynx and we started discussing details back and forth. In the mean time I kept hearing complaints from artists feeling that they were not being compensated enough for the use of their art. This was not a complaint against their fans at all, they were extremely appreciative of their fans support. 

One thing led to another and I discovered a few things that upset me and so I was even more determined than ever. It went from a project of, hey I want to have my own exclusive shirts for Littles Toy Company to sell, into now I am going to build a company that is going to truly be there for the artists.  I decided that it was time to pick a few artists brains to see what they thought was fair. I reached out to a bunch of artists and none were getting back to me, could have been busy prepping for conventions. A friend of mine told me to reach out to Leekfish and so I did. She was great and got back to me right away. We talked for a little while and pretty much had the same number in our minds. She helped to confirm what I was thinking. I reached out to JadedJynx with the offer and she accepted and so here we are.

We are trying to make the first joint effort between FandomWares (A Littles Toy Company subsidiary) and JadedJynx a reality. We need to be able to give WeLoveFine the total number of shirts, color and delivery date. So we are asking you, the fans, to reach out to us and let us know how many of you would love one of these amazing shirts. If you could also let us know what color shirt you think this design would look best  on, that would be amazing. We may only be able to offer one or two colors to start. If this is a successful start, we are looking to make this the first of a series. 

Below you will find contact info, so that you may reserve your Warrior Dash shirt. We will not be collecting any money right away but we do ask you only reserve if you are serious about purchasing one. Sizes will range from Men’s small up to 3X-Large, we might be able to do a couple sizes larger if your interested just let us know. Once we get approval, we will send out invoices and ask for your shipping addresses. We are hoping to have these for BronyCon. Thanks so much for all of your support and for being part of such an amazing community.


What We Need & What You Get (Donate What You Can, Any Support Is Greatly Appreciated)

We are looking to raise some start up capital so that this project can be a success. Any size donation will help to bring this project to life but if you make one of the minimum donations listed below you will secure yourself one of our exclusive shirts. Even if you are not a fan of this particular shirt we are working on, you can still donate and choose to receive a different shirt later on down the road. All you have to do is simply leave a comment with your donation stating I would like to receive a shirt of my choosing later on. We are currently having WeLoveFine manufacture the shirts for us. We compensate the artists for their design and we also give them a commission off of each shirt sold. Now you may ask, well what happens if this shirt is rejected by Hasbro and well that is an excellent question. If something happens and this shirt is indeed rejected by Hasbro, everyone who has donated enough to receive a shirt, will receive a certificate for one of our future shirts.  

$30 and up - You will get a shirt in your choice of size Small to X-Large - Shipping Included Within The United States.

$31 and up - If you need a shirt in a 2XL - Shipping Included Within The United States.

$32 and up - If you need a shirt in a 3XL - Shipping Included Within The United States.

Please feel free to reach out to us if you need an even larger shirt. We will be more than happy to see if that is available. 

The Impact

Now you may be asking well what does it matter if we have another apparel company. It does matter and here is why. One of our main goals is to give artists many new opportunities that they may have not had before. Artists that may have some of the most amazing art, might be left out of so many amazing opportunities simply because they don't have the popularity behind them. We want to give those amazing artists the exposure they deserve. Another one of our goals is to have an open door policy. Whats an open door policy you might ask? Well, we want to make sure that artists speak their minds. We don't ever want an artist to feel like they can't speak out and let us know they are unhappy with something. This happens so often where the artist doesn't feel like they can talk to the company they are working with freely. They feel there may be some financial consequences and any future work could be lost. We want the artists we work with to constantly be giving us feedback on how we are doing. We also want to make sure that artists never feel like they have to compromise their art. If one of the licensing companies come back with requests to change the art, the artist in no way will be forced to do so. If they are not comfortable with the requests, we can simply terminate the project if the artist so chooses to. Last but not least, we want to create a charity fund so that we may be able to help out those artists who might struggling within the community. Maybe the artist doesn't know when their next meal is, we will be able to supply them with some funds to go and buy some groceries. Maybe the artist has a really important convention coming up and is a little shy for the cost of their table. Maybe they already paid for their table but now need that plane ticket and its just out of reach. We want to be able to step in and help out. 

Risks & Challenges

I would say the biggest risk is not having the merchandise licensed and so that is why we are making sure everything we do is official. As far as challenges go, there will be legal fees, we may need to involve lawyers to try and help us out with the licensing process. Some big companies don't take you serious at first and so we may need to have lawyers draw up proposals. There may also be legal fees that may not involve the company directly. There may be that time that one of the artists within the community gets into legal trouble and is unfairly being picked on by big corporation A or B. We want to be able to step in and help out as much as possible. Last but not least, there is the challenge of denial, there is a possibility that some of the designs we submit will not be accepted by the companies we are trying to work with. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone will be able to contribute money to our project but you can still help. Simply tell everyone and anyone what it is we are trying to do. Make sure to send them over the link to our indiegogo page.

story:
What is this book about?

The Coloring Journal: 30 Doses of Sunshine for Mindful Living is a therapeutic activity book designed for stress relief and cultivating a mindful approach to life. Exposure to sunlight boosts the brain’s release of a hormone called serotonin, which is a natural mood enhancer and anti-depressant. Inspired by the latest research in positive psychology, this book will inspire you to color your way to sunshine. 


Defeat the dark forces of doom and gloom? How?

Use color pencils as your light saber! Defeat the dark forces of doom & gloom!
The Journal of American Art Therapy Association suggests that structured coloring of a moderately complex geometric pattern induces a meditative state that benefits people with anxiety. When the mind and body is focused on coloring, the fear center of the brain (the amygdala) is allowed to rest and relax. Calmness ensues. 

This book also contains breathing exercises, visualization activities, acts of kindness ideas, and reflection questions. These are designed to spark sunshine for a mindful life.


What are my steps to sunshiny mindfulness?

1. Turn to the content page. Eeny meeny miny moe. Pick one dose of sunshine.


2. Read. Reflect. Color. 


3. Sunshine Arises!


How did this book come about?

It began with an 800km walk...

...from France across Spain on The Way of St James (Camino de Santiago). I wrote about my walk - being alone, long silences, lessons from nature and exchanging life philosophies with fellow pilgrims .

And it bloomed into The Coloring Journal while hot air balloons drifted into the sunrise. 

Watching in silence while sunshine illuminated the landscape with vibrant hues of red and gold, my illustrator friend and I meditated on what had lead us here. What came to mind was my insomnia experience while working at an investment bank. To calm myself at night, I started coloring. Coloring became my therapeutic way of lowering anxiety and easing into a dreamless sleep (since pigging out on ice-cream would only add inches to my waistline and retail therapy reduce inches from my wallet). 

Inspired by the beauty before our eyes, we decided to combine our expertise to bring The Coloring Journal idea to full bloom.
Designed for the workaholic by day and insomniac by night, this book will  elevate your sunshine! Banish the dark forces of doom and gloom!

When can I get my hands (color pencils) on this? 


So this is the Deal...

For $5, three doses of sunshine in black and white for Gratitude, Peace and Compassion will be made available to backers in PDF format. Sunshine-in-progress examples here:


Journal Specifications 

For $12,  you will receive one travel size (6x9 inches) Coloring Journal for you to bring sunshine wherever whenever. Thick white paper (120gsm) from environmentally friendly sources will be used to print 76 black and white pages of the book.


Reaching for the Sun!

$5000 is what we need to make hay while the sun shines. This is to cover the costs associated with design, marketing, printing and freight.


What are the chances for any rain on this parade?

The book is 100% complete! We started working on this book in October 2015.

We will be working closely with a reputable printer to ensure the books are printed according to specifications.

International air freight will be handled by a trustworthy third party logistics company and local mail carriers will handle ground delivery to your shipping address.  Tracking numbers will be provided where available by local mail carriers.

story:
Hello, my name is Mark Andrew Webber.

A quick summary about this campaign. 

My aim is to create a giant 4 meter X 4 meter hand-carved typographic Linocut city map of Tokyo. This campaign is to raise funds for the initial stage of the project, which is the Research Phase (learning the language, initial walking around the city, getting to know the city). During this time I will be exploring the city, taking photos of the typography, drawing and designing.


About me and previous Maps

For me, there is something exciting about pushing limits and seeing just how far you can grow as a person. I'm an artist who is passionate about creating typographic city maps. Over the past 10 years I have created 5 city maps, each one pushing the boundaries of technique, size and complexity. I would like to push the limits of this latest map by increasing size, changing language and involving as many people in its creation as possible. That’s where you come in.

 A video of me carving the latest city map I created "Berlin" can be seen here:


This was 5 months of carving:- 7 days a week for about 12 - 16 hours a day. There is nothing better than focusing on a project & pushing yourself every single day. Including the Research Phase & design, the whole project took about 18 months.

With ‘Berlin’ I was able to create an interactive art event, inviting members of the public to help print the first copies of the map. I will be doing this eventually with the Tokyo Map as well.

I showed people how I inked up the plate, which took a few hours. I did get to make a couple of prints on my own with a spoon, and they took about 6 hours of spooning, to get the right amount of pressure equal over the whole Linocut.

My work is starting to gain some recognition in the wider Art and Design world And I do hope for that to continue. One of the highlights was when Erik Spiekermann paid a visit to the solo show to see progress of the map being printed.

So far city maps I have completed in order of date made:

New York:

London:

Amsterdam

Paris:

Berlin: 


How Your Support would help

With your support I will be able to complete this project ASAP! It would mean I could  invest full time into the project soon, rather than full time in however many years it takes. I'm determined to make the project a reality as it's my main focus in life. So getting your support on this would also mean a great deal personally. This project will also create a lot of different outcomes: Photography, timelapse footage, sketches, to public print events. Also the map created will be more like a puzzle so various size prints will be available. I hope as well that such a large scale project, would create some inspiration for others.

What I Need 

The money that I raise from this campaign will allow me to learn Japanese and to provide a slim stipend for food and accommodation whilst I get familiar with Tokyo and start taking the many photos and drawings that will go towards the planning for the final piece, the map itself. A big part of this project and every project I do is being able to understand the city and culture that I am in. Your donation will go towards helping to do that.

What You Get

You get regular updates of how the journey is going via a special blog.

Exclusive images of the typography that I find in Tokyo.

An exclusive video combining my photos, drawings and linocut images from the trip.

These benefits are for everyone that donates as well as the perks listed on the side.

Where do the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal?

The funds will go into a savings account & I will continue to raise money for this project through various art fair and exhibitions that I am taking part in. I have also applied for several art and design grants to make up any short fall. I am completely committed to making this happen.

Track Record for project completion

My main aims for life revolve around making art projects happen, improvement by setting challenges and completing them no matter what. 

I feel that all of my previous maps are proof of my commitment to completing projects, although this is my largest to date. I also feel that it is one that is the most creative and exciting. This project, due to its size and complexity, has captured the imagination of many of my close friends, colleagues and contemporaries around the world.  

Below I’ve added some of the other large scale projects I’ve undertaken.

 I Completed a piece for an exhibition in London called "The art of lost words" in which I had to make a piece about the "lost" word Dehisce (to Burst or Gape open(a pod or cut)).  

I decided to make a Hand carved animation. Which meant I had to Carve 297 pieces of Linoleum 10cm X 10cm each. which resulted in 297 prints, and animations of both the Linocuts / prints completed in about 2 months:

Prints scanned and animated:


Carvings scanned and animated:


I guarantee that this project will be completed. 

Risks & Challenges

Challenge in walking the city for an extended period of time. I plan to be spending up to 8 hours a day walking. I have arthritis (currently non active) this may mean that I need to change my schedule and the way that I work, taking extra days of not walking and completing sketches and carvings whilst my body recovers.

Challenge in carving, This is a big map and will take a long time to carve. I estimate based on the Berlin map over a year of solid carving. There are techniques I have developed to reduce the pressure on my hands.

Challenge in learning the language. Japanese is a complex written and spoken language so to try to minimize that challenge as much as possible I have already started learning Japanese. Konnichiwa!

Challenge in finding big enough paper - I might end up having to make the paper myself.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share the project even if you can not contribute, you can still contribute in a big way by just sharing the project. 

There are Indiegogo share tools, social networks can really get a campaign like this going.

I really Appreciate you taking the time to check this project out.

This was 5 months of carving:- 7 days a week for about 12 - 16 hours a day. There is nothing better than focusing on a project & pushing yourself every single day. Including the Research Phase & design, the whole project took about 18 months.
With ‘Berlin’ I was able to create an interactive art event, inviting members of the public to help print the first copies of the map. I will be doing this eventually with the Tokyo Map as well.



I showed people how I inked up the plate, which took a few hours. I did get to make a couple of prints on my own with a spoon, and they took about 6 hours of spooning, to get the right amount of pressure equal over the whole Linocut.
My work is starting to gain some recognition in the wider Art and Design world And I do hope for that to continue. One of the highlights was when Erik Spiekermann paid a visit to the solo show to see progress of the map being printed.


So far city maps I have completed in order of date made:
New York:

London:

Amsterdam

Paris:
Berlin: 


How Your Support would help
With your support I will be able to complete this project ASAP! It would mean I could  invest full time into the project soon, rather than full time in however many years it takes. I'm determined to make the project a reality as it's my main focus in life. So getting your support on this would also mean a great deal personally. This project will also create a lot of different outcomes: Photography, timelapse footage, sketches, to public print events. Also the map created will be more like a puzzle so various size prints will be available. I hope as well that such a large scale project, would create some inspiration for others.
What I Need 
The money that I raise from this campaign will allow me to learn Japanese and to provide a slim stipend for food and accommodation whilst I get familiar with Tokyo and start taking the many photos and drawings that will go towards the planning for the final piece, the map itself. A big part of this project and every project I do is being able to understand the city and culture that I am in. Your donation will go towards helping to do that.


What You Get
You get regular updates of how the journey is going via a special blog.
Exclusive images of the typography that I find in Tokyo.
An exclusive video combining my photos, drawings and linocut images from the trip.
These benefits are for everyone that donates as well as the perks listed on the side.

Where do the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal?
The funds will go into a savings account & I will continue to raise money for this project through various art fair and exhibitions that I am taking part in. I have also applied for several art and design grants to make up any short fall. I am completely committed to making this happen.

Track Record for project completion
My main aims for life revolve around making art projects happen, improvement by setting challenges and completing them no matter what. 
I feel that all of my previous maps are proof of my commitment to completing projects, although this is my largest to date. I also feel that it is one that is the most creative and exciting. This project, due to its size and complexity, has captured the imagination of many of my close friends, colleagues and contemporaries around the world.  
Below I’ve added some of the other large scale projects I’ve undertaken.
 I Completed a piece for an exhibition in London called "The art of lost words" in which I had to make a piece about the "lost" word Dehisce (to Burst or Gape open(a pod or cut)).  
I decided to make a Hand carved animation. Which meant I had to Carve 297 pieces of Linoleum 10cm X 10cm each. which resulted in 297 prints, and animations of both the Linocuts / prints completed in about 2 months:Prints scanned and animated:

Carvings scanned and animated:

I guarantee that this project will be completed. 
  Risks & Challenges

Challenge in walking the city for an extended period of time. I plan to be spending up to 8 hours a day walking. I have arthritis (currently non active) this may mean that I need to change my schedule and the way that I work, taking extra days of not walking and completing sketches and carvings whilst my body recovers.
Challenge in carving, This is a big map and will take a long time to carve. I estimate based on the Berlin map over a year of solid carving. There are techniques I have developed to reduce the pressure on my hands.
Challenge in learning the language. Japanese is a complex written and spoken language so to try to minimize that challenge as much as possible I have already started learning Japanese. Konnichiwa!
Challenge in finding big enough paper - I might end up having to make the paper myself.



    Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share the project even if you can not contribute, you can still contribute in a big way by just sharing the project. 
There are Indiegogo share tools, social networks can really get a campaign like this going.
I really Appreciate you taking the time to check this project out.

story:
What this is all about!

Hello Everyone!

We are Io Makandal ( South Africa ) and Samantha McCulloch ( Australia / South Africa) and this is our story!

We met back in 2007 when we were starry eyed and eager students studying Fine Art- an aspiration come true! Fast forward a few years when we graduated – We found ourselves in the real world determined to keep our art practices alive. We were both passionate about drawing, sculpture and interesting spaces and how we could use those mediums to explore and share stories with the world. So we began to collaborate on works together. Soon after as our collaboration was budding, Samantha left South Africa to pursue her studies further, leaving Makandal across the globe in South Africa. And so the From Where I Was: A Project in Parts was born, working apart across the globe. We sent drawings and objects to each other keeping the conversations going. Recently we found a way to connect to each other’s studios through a surveillance camera, which became a digital portal into each other’s spaces.

We are both passionate, committed artists and devoted cultural practitioners. This year we wanted to work together in the same space and invite the outside world through our “portal” to join with us on our journey. And with that we present the 4th part of our project: Bonus Space!

"Bonus Space takes its name from spaces designated public, but owned by the private sector in New York City. It will explore questions of intimacy, movement, confinement, ownership and instruction through sculpture, video, text, drawing and performance work. Responding to ongoing contests over urban space and the ‘right to the city’, this project will offer a timely and critical reflection on the conflicted nature of the public sphere in contemporary life. "

 We have been accepted into the NARS Foundation International Residency Program (hooray! we are VERY excited) to conduct our new project, and we need your help to make it happen!

This is an extremely important opportunity to us as artists. The New York Art Residency and Studios (NARS) Foundation is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit arts organization committed to supporting emerging and mid career artists and curators from around the world.  This intensive program brings together gifted and creative minds from diverse backgrounds who are dedicated to inquiry and art-making, to generate the most stimulative and rigorous environment possible for a concentrated period of artistic creation, interaction, exchange, and development. Thousands of applicants apply each year and we part of the fortunate (and grateful) few that have been accepted ( yaaaaaay!). 

Why we're doing this

At the NARS Foundation we will have concentrated time and space to realise our site specific project Bonus Space, create new work, connect with other artists and curators in a foreign place, develop our practice by participating in an important experience producing art away from home and to bring what we have experienced and learnt back to Johannesburg! Samantha and I want to take full advantage of this extremely awesome opportunity without getting ourselves into insurmountable debt. We live on a humble and tight budget at home and have been saving every extra penny for months. The start of the residency date is drawing nearer and we need to reach out to our global community for help to make this happen! 

So if you want to be a part of our journey and are in a position to contribute to our campaign and our project we will be immensely grateful for your support. Any and every bit helps us get there and make a dream come true! Thank you so much for your time and consideration.

Big love,

Samantha and Makandal

Why we need your help?

We've never asked for money like this before, but attending a residency like this as emerging artists is so important to our careers. We have a few small grants on our side, but we are still quite a way shy of our costs for the 3 month residency.
We are aiming to raise $ 5000 in 4 weeks! 
The funds raised will help us pay our way while we are in residence and cover costs for producing work.
If you donate ( yay & thank you!) your money will go towards the following:
  • The remaining cost of the NARS Foundation 2016 Season III International Artist Residency Program fee
  • Transportation to and from the residency studio. We will endeavour to walk as much as possible but time is also precious!
  • Travel costs from South Africa to USA. Ya... we look forward to the era in which one can teleport oneself from one place to another for free!
  •  Material and equipment costs to produce our project. We wish we were alchemists, but alas paper, drawing tools, resin, 32gb SD card, projector / screen hire, web design, cost money to make more amazing things!
  • Basic Living expenses: Food and accommodation. Got to eat and have a good night's sleep to be bright and fresh to think and make!
  • Museum / Gallery / Library cards so that we can explore, discover, research,  and expand our visual and literary horizon with the AMAZING Art galleries and collections in New York!
  • Shipping costs to bring with studio materials and to send back works produced and materials back home.

We want to give back to you too- What you get!

For your generosity in donating and investing to our careers we are giving some sweet perks ranging from Little Thank you, Big Thank you, Big biggggg feel good thank you, to brilliant artworks and more!

Why this is important?

Being an artist is a tricky profession ( We know many other professions are too, keep reading!) and often requires very clever creative problem solving to keep making our work and getting paid for it. Often it is only ourselves, friends and family (sometimes not even family) who root for us pushing our way through the world. Many question why we are artists if there are such high challenges on a day to day basis. Well, the truth is, we are born makers and story tellers. We are crazy, stupid in love with what we do and we give our lives for it. We put all our heart and soul into what we create and what we create is imbued with that love and shared with the world. Humans need art, questioning art, beautiful art, curious art, captivating art to be awed and instilled with wonder that connect us with our condition of being human.
This opportunity will launch our project on an international level, helping us grow our art practices and contribute to the growth of Contemporary South African art and cultural exchange at a significant and consequential time.

Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand, money is tight, but that doesn't mean you can't help us:

  • Tell your friends!  Make some noise and share our campaign on social media!
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

Thank you for you time and consideration!

story:
In 2014, six photographers came together from around the world to exhibit their work at Bank Street Arts in Sheffield. In September 2016, the same six photographers are coming back together in Oxford (UK) over a single weekend to create a body of work that will be shown a month later in Oxford (Canada) - a sort of cultural sharing of time, space and society between them.

Even though the six photographers live across the world (England, USA and Czech Republic), they all have some form of link to the English city of Oxford, even if it is just time spent there on holiday.

Bringing photographers together from around the globe for a weekend of creative activity is expensive, and is also subject to visa issues, travel delays and other problems. There is the potential for things to go horribly wrong. But we will overcome! It might be that there are only 5 that make it for the shooting weekend, or we may have to bring in another photographer for the exercise.

And the weather might not be what we wanted - this is England after all! But as Paul Klee once said "To emphasize only the beautiful seems to me to be like a mathematical system that only concerns itself with positive numbers". So if it rains, we'll cope with the negatives.

After the creative weekend, we have about a month to get everything together before a couple of us will be heading off to Canada. That will be a challenge too! We will aim to have everything sent off to our backers before the exhibition starts, but there is a chance it might be November - we will keep you all updated though!

The funding is required to assist with all aspects of the project, from actually bringing the 6 photographers together, production of the work, the catalogue, the associated paraphernalia, creating the exhibition itself and all the other associated costs of prints, mounts, frames, etc.  The money requested will not cover all of these the costs, far from it. When it comes to heading off to Canada for example, the flights will be self-funded by the photographers involved.

The Oxford Riverside Gallery in Oxford, Canada will be hosting the exhibition, with the opening night currently scheduled to take place on Friday 21st October. 

It is further hoped to bring the work back to Oxford (UK) in 2017 for a further exhibition, venue to be arranged. This is outside the scope of this campaign.

Even if you can't help us out financially in any way, donating or buying prints, etc. It would be great if you could shout this campaign out on your social media - it would mean a lot to us all!


http://six-scapes.weebly.com

#6oxford

The [( 6 )] artists are:

Tanya Ahmed - tanyaahmed.com 

Dewald Botha - dewaldbotha.net 

Rob™ - robtm.co.uk 

Keith Greenough - photo-graph.org 

Nigel Haworth - nigeljhaworth.com 

Pete Mansell - paralysed.weebly.com

story:
A unique opportunity

I have always loved the idea of creating a piece of art that does more than sit on a shelf - it serves a purpose as a mug, a bowl, a pitcher, or a plate!  In addition, I love sharing my passion for ceramics with others, and I find that outlet as a pottery instructor and as a host for monthly raku events.

 It isn't often that a ceramic artist outgrows their equipment, but with the death of a little old kiln comes the opportunity to upgrade to a larger kiln, enabling me to create more, and bigger pieces!  

How you can help

I am seeking seed money with which I will be able to purchase and wire a new kiln, as well as cover some of the extraneous costs associated with running a small studio.  

Please consider making a contribution today! If you do, you'll receive one of the great perks listed on the right!

If you can't make a contribution at this time, I hope you will consider sharing my campaign with your friends. Thank you!

For orders placed internationally, funder must pay shipping.

 

Also, if you want something else that you don't see here, please contact me!  I can set up a "secret perk" just for you!

story:
SWAG needs YOUR help to make our inaugural theater season a reality.

We need $10,000 by the end of August 2016 to help pay for the programs & stage productions we have planned which will include:

Fiddler on the Roof

SWAG Songbook Series

SWAG Table Read Series


Your tax-deductible gift helps us pay for things like:

Theater rental

Rehearsal space

Costumes

Scenery & Props

Director, Choreographer, Musical Director and Design Team

Rights of the Musical

Printing of scripts, scores & Playbills at the show!


YOU can make OUR dreams a reality!!! YOU make the difference. 

Your gift provides a life changing experience for our theater family. Making theater is a risky business, an uphill climb, and we don't make money off of this.  We must rely on the generosity of patrons to help create these works and bring them to life on stage.

Anything you can contribute helps bring our dreams to life! And there's more you can do! Some of you maybe can only afford a small contribution or maybe just can't contribute all, but you can still help us make a difference. Help us by BOOST THE SIGNAL and get the word out about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email and other social media outlets! Please use the Indiegogo Share Tools and help us! Speak from the heart and connect to people to let them know how important our cause is! Every little bit helps!

story:
Welcome!  Let me tell you WHAT my new book, Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand Unification is all about, and WHY it’s so very important that I’m asking for your help.

The Friday evening gathering of friends and family at synagogue, and at home around the dinner-table is the most cherished moment of the week in Jewish culture. Warmth and conversation, great food and a chance to breathe and rest after the busy work week…we receive Shabbat with all of these, all interwoven with the inspirational poetry and song, known as Kabbalat Shabbat, that lifts us to the heights of spiritual joy, that reconnect us to the Divine.


This exquisite book— at whose core are the paintings  like the ones in this video — presents these beloved traditions, compiled by the Kabbalists of sixteenth century Israel in an entirely new way! Not only is this the very first artistic presentation of this poetry, it is the first attempt of any kind—either in paint or in words—to interpret the liturgy in the light of the modern sciences that shape the world in which we live every day. Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand Unification helps us understand this five-hundred (and more) year old mystical tradition in a way that we, who live in the modern world shaped by rational science, can relate to and love…and appreciate with our modern minds as well as our traditional hearts. In our increasingly secular age, that offers us a how of life, but not always a why, this lovingly-produced book helps us probe the most fundamental questions of our spiritual lives in the light of both concrete reality and spiritual quest.

Here's a taste!


If you scroll down, you'll find other delightful 3 Minute Illumination Videos where I show and tell about certain illuminations of prayers and blessings in the book.

Let me tell you something about myself and the amazing scholars collaborating with me, and discuss why I’m asking you to contribute.

Who am I, and what’s this project all about?

I’m Debra Band, Hebrew manuscript artist and author of The Song of Songs: the Honeybee in the Garden, I Will Wake the Dawn: Illuminated Psalms, and Arise! Arise! Deborah, Ruth and Hannah, and creator of hundreds of original and limited edition  ketubot (Jewish marriage documents).  My celebrated work in Hebrew illuminated manuscripts draws upon my passions for the manuscript arts and Jewish traditions and studies.  In the video above (with cockatiel)  you can watch over my shoulder as I paint, and you can read more about my background below.

New translations of the poetry and blessings have been done by the leading scholar of medieval Jewish poetry, Raymond P. Scheindlin, of the Jewish Theological Seminary, translator and author of many leading works on Hebrew poetry and Jewish liturgy. The world-renowned leader of the international Jewish community, and former Chief Rabbi of United Synagogue Great Britain, and prolific author, Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks, has contributed an elegant foreword, and the senior scholar of Jewish mysticism, Arthur Green, dean of the inter-denominational rabbinical school at Boston's Hebrew College, and author of many works on Jewish mysticism has prepared a preface for the work.

Your help is essential in bringing Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand Unification to light. This project is the most adventurous realization of my life-long twin passions for fusing inspiring artwork with Jewish culture.  Each of my acclaimed books weaves my own creativity together with Hebrew Bible, with midrash and other rabbinics, academic bible and historical study, archeology and science—in partnership with leading scholars of Jewish studies.  You may click on the links above to learn more about me, about my earlier work, and most importantly about this project—and please help fund me to bring this important (and luscious) book into the light in April 2016. I'm offering wonderful perks, topped by an original sterling silver, garnet and glass kiddush cup designed by the wonderful silversmith, Ruth Shapiro, to accompany the book, available here for the first time.

A Work of Love (not profit)! This book, like all of my books, is a labor of love. Art books, in particular religious art books are rarely profitable—far from it.  Speaking from my own experience, all three of my previous books, whether published by JPS or under my own imprint, were entirely underwritten by major donors for the sake of their cultural value. None were undertaken or financed with the expectation of eventual profit, nor achieved it.  This project has absorbed more than 2 years of my own time in painting, and more than that in study and research. The funds that I am seeking to raise do not begin to reimburse me or my collaborators for the months and years spent in creating artwork, translations and commentary materials, nor the many hours of exacting proof-reading and editing that have been so graciously offered gratis by skilled friends.  Sales proceeds will barely begin to be remuneration for the time and efforts absorbed by this important project. Fortunately, my patrons, Steven and Sharon Lieberman, appreciate this fully, and have funded actual printing costs with no expectation of financial return.  Yet, additional hard expenses above and beyond printing include: travel, materials ($3000 for calfskin vellum alone, ~$1500 in gold leaf, paints and other supplies), studio insurance and other studio expenses, book design, print coordination, distribution expenses, shipping, marketing, advertising and exhibit expenses. My work inspires such enduring enthusiasm among my readers that I have welcomed the advent of crowd-sourcing as a democratic means of enabling my readers, long-connected as well as new, to participate in the exciting process of bringing such a work to light.  Each of you will enjoy the satisfaction of knowing that you have participated in the creation of a new landmark in contemporary Jewish culture.  I appreciate your support!

If you'd like a taste of the way I meld all these kinds of thought into glowing and meaningful art, please come back often! I'm posting videos about different pairs of paintings every now and then over the next weeks. Enjoy...and then read on (and please contribute!)




More about the Authors
I hold a BA Honours in History from Concordia University in Montreal and an MS in Political Science from MIT, and turned full attention to Hebrew manuscript arts in 1987. My work grows from my childhood fascination with book illustration and the traditions of my family, an eminent  British rabbinic and scholarly line that goes back to the early Hasidic master, the Berditchever Rav.  Upon marrying my beloved late first husband, David, I acquired the renowned scholar of Hebrew literature, Arnold J. Band, not only as father-in-law, but also as my mentor. My extensive studies of Jewish texts, academic biblical studies, archeology, and research into medieval European and middle Eastern painting and manuscripts are fundamental to my art. My work resides in exhibits, private collections, community institutions and galleries across the English-speaking world. I speak and teach regularly in Jewish and Christian organizations across the US, Canada and the UK.  In addition to my "day-job" as an artist and writer, for nearly ten years I have participated in medical ethics review review activities at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland (my way of "giving back" in return for NIH staff's long years of superlative care of my beloved first husband).

My collaborator, Raymond P. Scheindlin, who has prepared the poetry translations and literary commentaries is Professor of Medieval Hebrew Literature and director of the Shalom Spiegel Institute of Medieval Hebrew Poetry,  Jewish Theological Seminary of America.  He is the author of Wine, Women and Death: Medieval Hebrew Poems on the Good Life; The Gazelle: Medieval Hebrew Poetry on God, Israel and the Soul; A Short History of the Jewish People; The Song of the Distant Dove: Judah Halevi’s Pilgrimage; and a verse translation of the Book of Job.  He was the recipient of the Cultural Achievement Award of the National Foundation for Jewish Culture in 2004.

What kind of funding do I need?

Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand Unification, which is the second book I’m publishing myself through my Honeybee in the Garden, LLC, will require about $80,000 to launch properly—not only printing, but other activities such as graphic design, creation of the traveling exhibit of the original paintings, marketing and promotional activities, reimbursing me for the costly materials and studio expenses involved in creating the work, a book tour, etc. Steven and Sharon Lieberman, leaders within the American Jewish community—and repeated supporters of my work— have already funded the printing with a gift of $20,000, and I need your help now to fund the other essential activities. Publishing a high-quality book is expensive!

Your generous contribution will fund the following:

Graphic Design  $10,000

Studio and Materials Expenses  $19,000

PR, Marketing, Book Tour, Ads  $20,000

Exhibit Expenses  $11,000

TOTAL    $60,000 to be funded through this campaign

These projected expenses are based on my experiences with all my previous three books. If this campaign does not raise the full amount, your contribution will be well and carefully used, but certain expenditures will be reduced accordingly.  Even if you cannot contribute significant funds, please do spread the word, and use Indiegogo's share tools to invite your own friends into this adventure.

I hope you will participate generously in funding this project.  Not only will you join me to bring this exquisite and inspirational book into the world, but, in the context of the increasingly secular nature of our surrounding culture—think of the 2014 Pew Report on Jews and Judaism— you will help me make an important contribution to the health of traditional Jewish life for all our families as we move into the future.  This is an important project.
story_txt:
Welcome!  Let me tell you WHAT my new book, Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand Unification
is all about, and WHY it’s so very important that I’m asking for your help.



The Friday evening gathering of friends and
family at synagogue, and at home around the dinner-table is the most cherished
moment of the week in Jewish culture. Warmth and conversation, great food and a
chance to breathe and rest after the busy work week…we receive Shabbat with all
of these, all interwoven with the inspirational poetry and song, known as
Kabbalat Shabbat, that lifts us to the heights of spiritual joy, that reconnect
us to the Divine.

This exquisite book— at whose core are the paintings  like the ones in this video — presents these beloved
traditions, compiled by the Kabbalists of sixteenth century Israel in an
entirely new way! Not only is this the very first artistic presentation of
this poetry, it is the first attempt of any kind—either in paint or in words—to interpret the
liturgy in the light of the modern sciences that shape the world in which we
live every day. Kabbalat Shabbat: the
Grand Unification helps us understand this five-hundred (and more) year old
mystical tradition in a way that we, who live in the modern world shaped by
rational science, can relate to and love…and appreciate with our modern minds
as well as our traditional hearts. In our increasingly secular age, that offers
us a how of life, but not always a why, this lovingly-produced book helps
us probe the most fundamental questions of our spiritual lives in the light of
both concrete reality and spiritual quest.
Here's a taste!

If you scroll down, you'll find other delightful 3 Minute Illumination Videos where I show and tell about certain illuminations of prayers and blessings in the book.
Let me tell you
something about myself and the amazing scholars collaborating with me,
and discuss why I’m asking you to contribute. 

Who am I, and what’s this project all about?

I’m Debra
Band, Hebrew manuscript artist and author of The Song of
Songs: the Honeybee in the Garden, I Will Wake the Dawn: Illuminated
Psalms, and Arise! Arise! Deborah,
Ruth and Hannah, and creator of hundreds of original and limited
edition  ketubot (Jewish
marriage documents).  My celebrated work
in Hebrew illuminated manuscripts draws upon my passions for the manuscript
arts and Jewish traditions and studies.  In the video above (with cockatiel)  you can watch over my shoulder as I paint, and you can read more about my background below.
New translations of the poetry and blessings have been done by the leading scholar of medieval Jewish poetry, Raymond P. Scheindlin, of the Jewish Theological Seminary, translator and author of many leading works on Hebrew poetry and Jewish liturgy. The world-renowned leader of the international Jewish community, and former Chief Rabbi of United Synagogue Great Britain, and prolific author, Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks, has contributed an elegant foreword, and the senior scholar of Jewish mysticism, Arthur Green, dean of the inter-denominational rabbinical school at Boston's Hebrew College, and author of many works on Jewish mysticism has prepared a preface for the work. 
Your help is essential in bringing Kabbalat Shabbat: the Grand
Unification to light. This project is the most adventurous realization of my life-long twin
passions for fusing inspiring artwork with Jewish culture.  Each of my acclaimed books weaves my own
creativity together with Hebrew Bible, with midrash and other rabbinics, academic
bible and historical study, archeology and science—in partnership with leading
scholars of Jewish studies.  You may click on the links above
to learn more about me, about my earlier work, and most importantly 
about this project—and please help fund me to bring this important
(and luscious) book into the light in April 2016. I'm offering wonderful
 perks, topped by an original sterling silver, garnet and glass kiddush cup designed by the wonderful silversmith, Ruth Shapiro, to accompany the book, available here for the first time. 





A Work of Love (not profit)! This book, like all of my books, is a labor of love. Art
books, in particular religious art books are rarely profitable—far from
it.  Speaking from my own experience, all
three of my previous books, whether published by JPS or under my own imprint,
were entirely underwritten by major donors for the sake of their cultural
value. None were undertaken or financed with the expectation of eventual
profit, nor achieved it.  This project
has absorbed more than 2 years of my own time in painting, and more than that in
study and research. The funds that I am seeking to raise do not begin
to reimburse me or my collaborators for the months and years spent in creating artwork,
translations and commentary materials, nor the many hours of exacting
proof-reading and editing that have been so graciously offered gratis by
skilled friends.  Sales proceeds will
barely begin to be remuneration for the time and efforts absorbed by this
important project. Fortunately, my patrons, Steven and Sharon Lieberman,
appreciate this fully, and have funded actual printing costs with no
expectation of financial return.  Yet,
additional hard expenses above and beyond printing include: travel, materials ($3000 for calfskin vellum alone, ~$1500
in gold leaf, paints and other supplies), studio insurance and other studio expenses, book design, print
coordination, distribution expenses, shipping, marketing, advertising and
exhibit expenses. My work inspires such enduring enthusiasm among my readers
that I have welcomed the advent of crowd-sourcing as a democratic means of enabling my
readers, long-connected as well as new, to participate in the exciting process
of bringing such a work to light.  Each
of you will enjoy the satisfaction of knowing that you have participated in the
creation of a new landmark in contemporary Jewish culture.  I appreciate your support!

My collaborator, Raymond P. Scheindlin, who has prepared the poetry translations and literary commentaries 
is Professor of Medieval Hebrew Literature and director of
the Shalom Spiegel Institute of Medieval Hebrew Poetry,  Jewish Theological Seminary of America.  He is the author of Wine, Women and Death: Medieval Hebrew Poems on the Good Life; The Gazelle: Medieval Hebrew Poetry on God,

and a verse translation of the Book of Job.

Grand Unification, which is the second book I’m publishing myself through

through this campaign

all my previous three books. I hope you will participate generously in funding this
project.  Not only will you join me to bring
this exquisite and inspirational book into the world, but, in the
context of the increasingly secular nature of our surrounding culture—think of

story:
ANYWAYS, HERE'S THE BLUES

An 80 page 9x12 deluxe soft cover illustrated book honoring America's legendary blues musicians. Paying respect to 30 of America's most original and influential musicians
with a collection of stories and illustrations.

Looking through Muddy Waters let me see clearly

Years ago, I held the bright idea to write a book about drawing. I found the entire process of  ‘writing’ this book a beige and taxing slog. 

Running in parallel to this experience, I was always still drawing. One afternoon, I had the inspiration to illustrate Muddy Waters. His drawing evoked so much enjoyment and satisfaction that I considered how cool it would be to do more of them... It dawned on me that I could do whatever I wanted.

If I'm going to create something, I want to love what I'm creating. Considering how much I love the blues, Muddy Waters' illustration gave me clarity to see what I really wanted!



 

Giving Back

The Delta Blues Foundation is a qualified 501 (c) (3) tax-exempt organization. All funds solicited through the Delta Blues Foundation are raised on behalf of benefiting the Delta Blues Museum.

I am donating a percentage of the final campaign results to support this great charity.

You can find out more about them here:
https://www.deltabluesmuseum.org
 



 

PERKS!

1. A signed copy of the book
2. A signed copy of the book with a custom sketch. Maybe you're more of a SRV fan or Jimi Hendrix fan... request your favorite.
3. A signed copy of the book with a custom sketch.
PLUS, the original illustration of Howlin Wolf.
This was the art used in the book.
3. A signed copy of the book with a custom sketch.
PLUS, the original illustration of Charlie Patton.
This was the art used in the book.
3. A signed copy of the book with a custom sketch.
PLUS, the original illustration of Billie Holiday.
This was the art used in the book.

Here's the Howlin' Wolf illustration. It actually has crushed red velvet backing.

 

STRETCH GOALS!

Depending on the success of the campaign, there will be additional one-of-a-kind offers.
Stickers, posters, garments, and even more.

Updates coming as we make this happen together!
