story:
Summary

Hello, my name is Eric Plant. I am the designer and creator of Liminal Spaces. Conceived as the result of my own experiences with dreams, hypnagogia, lucid dreaming, and insomnia, Liminal Spaces attempts to bring that suspended moment to life and explore the relevant themes and moments surrounding that moment.

By contributing to this project, you not only help to see this project come to life, but you also help to move my future projects and career forward. Being my inaugural project, Liminal Spaces is an increasingly important project!

What We Need & What You Get

Liminal Spaces is a large project and thus, requires a good amount of funds to be fully realized.

  • We are looking for $1650 in order to rent out the exhibit space in Los Angeles for 6 hours, buy the necessary materials and fees in order to create the pieces in the installation, create merchandise, and cover any extra costs involved in the project.
  • By donating, you will receive Perks in return for your kindness and generosity.
    • Receive a Facebook Shoutout when you donate $5!
    • Receive a shoutout in the event program when you donate $15 along with the previous donation perk of a Facebook shoutout!
    • Receive a Liminal Spaces tote bag when you donate $30 along with the previous donation perks!
    • Receive a Liminal Spaces T-shirt when you donate $75 along with the previous donation perks!
    • Receive a 12" x 12" photo of the bed piece from the installation when you donate $100 along with the previous donation perks!

If we don't reach the entire goal, any funds raised will still go towards the project and the installation will still be completed.

The Impact

This project has a large impact. To start, this project, being my first, is incredibly important to building my resume and career in the art installation world. I believe it is important to support young artists like myself as they embark on the blind and unsure journey that is becoming an artist out in the world. 

Liminal Spaces as a concept is important to explore as well

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute but would still love to help?

  • Share this campaign and get the word out!!
  • Feel free to send me encouraging notes through Facebook or art.ericplant@gmail.com!!
  • Tell your friends!

story:
InGenieous debuted at the regional burn Lakes of Fire 2018 - and we burned plenty of midnight oil to get it there!  After a wonderful outpouring of support, we’re making improvements from our own wish list to get things ready for the Black Rock City!  To make the magic go even further, we need your help, fellow Djinns and Genies! 

 

InGenieous is a collaboration between artistic and life partners Matt Helsel and Annie Framstad and a uniquely skilled team of Chicago Burners.  Matt is a union iron worker who has built and had a hand (and heart) in designing art pieces from The Midwest to the playa and back again. Annie is a multidisciplinary artist whose art focuses on fabric design, interaction, and creating spaces and ambiance.

 

We’ve self-funded this project up to this point, and we’ve realized in building a gift for our community, we can only do so much without the help of our community. Please donate some money to InGenieous if you can, and if you can’t please share our campaign with your friends and help us reach our goal.

 

All the funds we raise will go directly to transportation costs, energy costs to keep the interior air conditioned, completing the gold cover made of vinyl and finishing up all the other details we have on our wish list!  Funding this project is co-creating an intentional space based around gifting and civic engagement. You've heard of glamping, now come try out lamping!

 

Thank you for help making our wishes come true, please visit us on playa so we can return the favor! Please watch this video made with the talents and love of Simon Rubenstein, and help make our wishes come true! 

 

Infinite love and gratitude to you for supporting us, and thank you for your Genie-rosity! <3<3<3

story:
Art supporting the environment

I will create a series of eight woodcut prints featuring the forest's iconic wiliwili tree, along with other important endemic species of shrubs, trees, flowers and grasses that inhabit this special place.  An artist's statement telling the story of the plants and ecosystem depicted in each image will be displayed with each print. A special community exhibition will be held to celebrate the project and introduce the Waikoloa Dry Forest to more people. 20% of the contributions will be donated to The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative.

This ancient wiliwili tree survived the feral goats' voracious appetites.

Why is this project important?   

The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative stewards a 275-acre forest preserve that encompasses some of the last remaining dryland forest in South Kohala. While only about 10 percent or less of this native ecosystem still exists in Hawai'i, important species, including the endangered wiliwili trees, are still thriving under the care of the land managers in Waikoloa. Their work focuses on restoring the area with trees, shrubs and grasses that were once abundant in the region and raising awareness about this special ecosystem.

 In ancient times, forests thrived just fine without human help. Because this fragile environment has endured hundreds of years of impact by humans, this forest needs our help to become a richly diverse ecosystem once again. It takes expert management and a dedicated community to restore a forest.

For The Eternal Wiliwili Forest project, I'll create a series of prints that tell a story of the evolution of The Waikoloa Dry Forest at this moment in time.  The forest itself, and this body of art and storytelling is a legacy for future generations

My Background

I am a professional artist, specializing in printmaking. Over the past 18 years my work has focused on the native species of Hawai'i.  Because my educational background is in archaeology,  I bring an awareness of the cultural and historical significance of the endangered ecosystems of Hawaii to my art. I am passionate about creating beautiful and evocative images that inspire people to care about these special plants and ecosystems that are so important to the environmental and cultural well-being of Hawai'i.

I planted my first tree at the Waikoloa Dry Forest six years ago and fell in love with this place. This led to a series of six woodcut prints featuring the ecosystem of the forest, including two botanical portraits. The Executive Director of the forest, botanist Jen Lawson, supported my efforts with information so that I could merge the worlds of art and botany with accuracy.  I then coordinated a group exhibition and fundraiser for the WDFI.

My art is exhibited in several of Hawaii's premier galleries on Maui and the Big Island. Learn more about me and enjoy my art on my website at andreapro.com.

My process in creating a series of prints

First, I gather knowledge and impressions by volunteering on forest work days and participating in community tours. We gather seeds, plant trees and shrubs and transplant in the nursery. I listen and learn from forest managers as they share about the plants and forest.  I roam around sketching and photographing plants, and occasionally hug the ancient wiliwili trees that dot the landscape. This project will involve many visits to the forest and conversations with the forest managers and other experts, like ornithologists and entomologists, in my quest to understand the essence of the plants and dry forest ecosystem.

Next, I incubate all of my impressions and finally start to compose themes for each work of art and sketch the compositions.  From there I transfer the image to the blocks and begin carving and printing. My prints are produced in limited editions, usually 20 - 30 original prints for each image.  For this project I anticipate beginning the sketching and carving in early November, with all prints completed by the end of March 2020.

How Your Contribution will be Used

1. Funding the art project and community exhibition.  

The expenses for this project include paper at $1,800, framing at $3,000, tools and ink at $200, for a total of $5,000.  I plan to produce limited editions of 20 - 30 prints for each image. I'll need to purchase special custom-cut Japanese woodblocks, archival paper, inks and other tools. Framing the prints for the exhibition  will be the biggest expense. Printmaking is a time consuming medium. Each print requires carving multiple blocks and printing each block on each sheet of paper on my press in my studio.  Your contribution will also support me during the months of time and effort it will take to create this project. In return you'll receive art that is priced below retail level. Once the project is complete prices will increase to market value.

2.  Funds for the Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative.

The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative will receive 20% of all funds contributed and will apply the funds to their native tree planing program. Learn more about WDFI at waikoloadryforest.org

If I don't reach my goal of $15,000.00, the funds I do receive will be used to cover these project expenses first.  That way I can still complete the series and we can have the exhibition. The exhibition alone will benefit the Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative through community involvement.

20% of funds will be donated to WDFI after the contributions cover project expenses. In addition I'll give WDFI the licensing rights to two images to use for a mural and for tee shirts or other products.

Questions?   

Feel free to reach out to me or  Jen Lawson, Executive Director of the forest. Go to waikoloadryforest.org and click contact link at bottom of the page.                                                                                                                                                                         

Why do a Fundraiser?

To create a forest, we need to rally together!  In addition to offering financial support for this project and to the forest, this campaign will generate events and more community connections that bring people to the forest. People who experience the forest support the forest.

The Waikoloa Dry Forest has thrived because of the energy of a large and diverse community of invested participants.  This project, with it's focus on celebrating and documenting the forest through art and storytelling, will reach even more people who will want to be involved. As a contributor, you'll be part of the community and history of the Waikoloa Dry Forest.

 

About Your Perks

The perks I'm offering fall in two categories:  greeting cards and botanical pillows that are commercially printed from my art designs and original art that will be produced over the next six months. You'll be able to see the cards here and the pillow choices on my website.

 I realize that when you choose original art as your perk, you are choosing art sight unseen. That takes trust!  I encourage you to explore the art I have posted here and on my website to get a clear idea of my style and color palette.

See my art and get to know me at andreapro.com.  I'd love to hear from you! Contact me through this platform or my site.                                                                     

Your additional perks:  We will let you know when Forest tours and visits to my studio are scheduled so you can join us. With great appreciation, I'll give you a Mahalo on my Facebook page to thank you for your contribution.

Risks and Challenges 

Any weighty project comes with risks and challenges, after all that is what helps us grow and learn.  I have worked on complex art projects and exhibitions both as a solo artist and in collaboration with other artists.  I'm very persistent in solving the inevitable challenges that each project presents, and I also have a highly developed sense of integrity! You can be assured that I'll give this project 150% of my energy and I'll keep you posted about developments along the way.

Spread the word!

After pledging your support, please help to spread the word about this project by sharing this link with your friends, family and work colleagues:

https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/the-eternal-wiliwili-forest/edit#/story

 Don't forget to share on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social media platforms too.....
story_txt:
Art supporting the environment
I will create a series of eight woodcut prints featuring the forest's iconic wiliwili tree, along with other important endemic species of shrubs, trees, flowers and grasses that inhabit this special place.  An artist's statement telling the story of the plants and ecosystem depicted in each image will be displayed with each print. A special community exhibition will be held to celebrate the project and introduce the Waikoloa Dry Forest to more people. 20% of the contributions will be donated to The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative.

This ancient wiliwili tree survived the feral goats' voracious appetites.

Why is this project important?   
The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative stewards a 275-acre forest preserve that encompasses some of the last remaining dryland forest in South Kohala. While only about 10 percent or less of this native ecosystem still exists in Hawai'i, important species, including the endangered wiliwili trees, are still thriving under the care of the land managers in Waikoloa. Their work focuses on restoring the area with trees, shrubs and grasses that were once abundant in the region and raising awareness about this special ecosystem.
 In ancient times, forests thrived just fine without human help. Because this fragile environment has endured hundreds of years of impact by humans, this forest needs our help to become a richly diverse ecosystem once again. It takes expert management and a dedicated community to restore a forest.
For The Eternal Wiliwili Forest project, I'll create a series of prints that tell a story of the evolution of The Waikoloa Dry Forest at this moment in time.  The forest itself, and this body of art and storytelling is a legacy for future generations
My Background
I am a professional artist, specializing in printmaking. Over the past 18 years my work has focused on the native species of Hawai'i.  Because my educational background is in archaeology,  I bring an awareness of the cultural and historical significance of the endangered ecosystems of Hawaii to my art. I am passionate about creating beautiful and evocative images that inspire people to care about these special plants and ecosystems that are so important to the environmental and cultural well-being of Hawai'i.

I planted my first tree at the Waikoloa Dry Forest six years ago and fell in love with this place. This led to a series of six woodcut prints featuring the ecosystem of the forest, including two botanical portraits. The Executive Director of the forest, botanist Jen Lawson, supported my efforts with information so that I could merge the worlds of art and botany with accuracy.  I then coordinated a group exhibition and fundraiser for the WDFI.
My art is exhibited in several of Hawaii's premier galleries on Maui and the Big Island. Learn more about me and enjoy my art on my website at andreapro.com.
My process in creating a series of prints
First, I gather knowledge and impressions by volunteering on forest work days and participating in community tours. We gather seeds, plant trees and shrubs and transplant in the nursery. I listen and learn from forest managers as they share about the plants and forest.  I roam around sketching and photographing plants, and occasionally hug the ancient wiliwili trees that dot the landscape. This project will involve many visits to the forest and conversations with the forest managers and other experts, like ornithologists and entomologists, in my quest to understand the essence of the plants and dry forest ecosystem.
Next, I incubate all of my impressions and finally start to compose themes for each work of art and sketch the compositions.  From there I transfer the image to the blocks and begin carving and printing. My prints are produced in limited editions, usually 20 - 30 original prints for each image.  For this project I anticipate beginning the sketching and carving in early November, with all prints completed by the end of March 2020.
How Your Contribution will be Used
1. Funding the art project and community exhibition.  
The expenses for this project include paper at $1,800, framing at $3,000, tools and ink at $200, for a total of $5,000.  I plan to produce limited editions of 20 - 30 prints for each image. I'll need to purchase special custom-cut Japanese woodblocks, archival paper, inks and other tools. Framing the prints for the exhibition  will be the biggest expense. Printmaking is a time consuming medium. Each print requires carving multiple blocks and printing each block on each sheet of paper on my press in my studio.  Your contribution will also support me during the months of time and effort it will take to create this project. In return you'll receive art that is priced below retail level. Once the project is complete prices will increase to market value.
2.  Funds for the Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative.
The Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative will receive 20% of all funds contributed and will apply the funds to their native tree planing program. Learn more about WDFI at waikoloadryforest.org
If I don't reach my goal of $15,000.00, the funds I do receive will be used to cover these project expenses first.  That way I can still complete the series and we can have the exhibition. The exhibition alone will benefit the Waikoloa Dry Forest Initiative through community involvement.
20% of funds will be donated to WDFI after the contributions cover project expenses. In addition I'll give WDFI the licensing rights to two images to use for a mural and for tee shirts or other products.
Questions?   
Feel free to reach out to me or  Jen Lawson, Executive Director of the forest. Go to waikoloadryforest.org and click contact link at bottom of the page.                                                                                                                                                                          
Why do a Fundraiser?
To create a forest, we need to rally together!  In addition to offering financial support for this project and to the forest, this campaign will generate events and more community connections that bring people to the forest. People who experience the forest support the forest.
The Waikoloa Dry Forest has thrived because of the energy of a large and diverse community of invested participants.  This project, with it's focus on celebrating and documenting the forest through art and storytelling, will reach even more people who will want to be involved. As a contributor, you'll be part of the community and history of the Waikoloa Dry Forest.
 
About Your Perks
The perks I'm offering fall in two categories:  greeting cards and botanical pillows that are commercially printed from my art designs and original art that will be produced over the next six months. You'll be able to see the cards here and the pillow choices on my website.
 I realize that when you choose original art as your perk, you are choosing art sight unseen. That takes trust!  I encourage you to explore the art I have posted here and on my website to get a clear idea of my style and color palette.
See my art and get to know me at andreapro.com.  I'd love to hear from you! Contact me through this platform or my site.                                                                      
Your additional perks:  We will let you know when Forest tours and visits to my studio are scheduled so you can join us. With great appreciation, I'll give you a Mahalo on my Facebook page to thank you for your contribution.
Risks and Challenges  
Any weighty project comes with risks and challenges, after all that is what helps us grow and learn.  I have worked on complex art projects and exhibitions both as a solo artist and in collaboration with other artists.  I'm very persistent in solving the inevitable challenges that each project presents, and I also have a highly developed sense of integrity! You can be assured that I'll give this project 150% of my energy and I'll keep you posted about developments along the way.
Spread the word!
After pledging your support, please help to spread the word about this project by sharing this link with your friends, family and work colleagues:
https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/the-eternal-wiliwili-forest/edit#/story
 Don't forget to share on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social media platforms too.....

story:
About Encore Clarinet

We believe Clarinet is the most beautiful instruments in the world. We are a team of clarinet lovers and artists, with our clarinet factory line and perfectionists musicians, designers, and engineers. Our sole purpose is to find a connection between Music and Arts, and apply to our instruments.

 

What is "Kintsugi" ?


Kintsugi means Golden Rejoining in Japanese (金継ぎ). It is a traditional Japanese art form.
Its meaning is to bring the fragmented parts of ourselves together in a way, to transcend from the original version. 

 

 

KSG Series Clarinet Products:

Encore Clarinet KSG series features 6 versions of clarinet barrels and bells. All made of aged African Ebony Wood.  Majesty, Empress, Bishop, Knight, Rook S, Rook G, Pawn S, Pawn G

The progress of making a KSG model can take up to 7 days. Our professional artist carefully handmade each one of the barrel/bell/ligature with extreme care, 
in a vision for the perfect combination of arts and music. 

All the paints are real gold/silver paint. It adds value to the products, and the older it gets, the more value it has. They are not only the necessary part for the clarinet but life-long art piece that forever belongs to the owner. 

KSG series has the perfect resonation with every clarinet model. Because of our choice of wood and the aging process. 

Barrel and Bell products feature inserted copper ring. Which enable the full resonance of the wood, and to deliver your sound to the end of the chamber.

Named after the chess pieces, each inseparable from others. We highly recommend purchasing a set of Barrel + Bell + Ligature, for the best resonance. 

 
 

Compare to others:

The KSG series exceeds all other existing clarinet companies. Since we not only make the product but to treat it as it sings with life. As musicians, we need to have a soulful connection with your instruments. 
In Encore Clarinet, we hand-select the darkest wood with the best resonance. To shape, to craft, to paint, to make each one of them alive.

Our musical art piece speaks for themselves, just waiting for the right owner to give them a chance to shine and sing. We also believe that the best sound quality clarinet and accessories should be affordable for all professional musicians.

A clarinet bell SHOULD NOT go up to 500 dollars, no excuses. However, the value of the instrument should be added together with the music of the owner. The true value is not in money, but the music and influence one can make.

In one Backun or Buffet bell's price, you can purchase a full set of Encore KSG series, that includes a barrel, bell, and a ligature. All made from the top tier African Ebony wood, with quality surpassing its competition by far.

 

 

Only 100 pieces of limited version for each version of KSG series. Encore Clarinet sought an environmentally friendly solution, and all our products are limited versions. So we can protect our environment and trees from over-deforestation and wasting. Each unit is labeled with a serial number, so reserve the one that belongs to you now.

 

 

Other Benefit of owning a KSG series:


- Free promotion for all your future events and music events on @encoreclarinet and @clarinet Instagram profile.
- List as the proud owner of Encore clarinet product, KSG Series owner
- Lifetime value guaranteed, treat it as an art piece, no devaluation, the older it gets, the more valuable it is.
- Shared resources, opportunities, gigs, and concerts within the Encore Clarinet community
- Stand out from the crowd, in any music setting. Whether you are in orchestra, solo performance, festival, small venue. KSG series guarantee you will get the most attention from audience.
- Early start on future Free give away, which we give away a free clarinet accessory every month, that includes ligatures, reed case, and even limited KSG series!

 


 

Follow us on social media:

Instagram @Encoreclarinet: https://www.instagram.com/encoreclarinet/
Instagram @Clarinet: https://www.instagram.com/clarinet/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/clarineti
YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCYnNiXVxeSTtKD...?

story:
The Students

The Tahoe Underground Film Festival is being organized and presented through a unique combination of classroom and student government collaboration here at Sierra Nevada College. We are located on the north shore of Lake Tahoe, in the great state of Nevada.

Sierra Nevada College is a small private liberal arts campus, with a vibrant Fine Arts Department. The Tahoe Underground Film Festival (TUFF) is being organized, in part, to expand our reach and exposure to contemporary visual arts practice. It also provides a venue for independent artists working in film, video and other visual media to access a wider audience.

Tahoe is a destination location, one of the most photographed places in the world. This winter, TUFF will add it to a list of cities exhibiting the very newest visual artists. Our initial call received more than 2,000 entries from over 90 countries. 

So Many Entries

In order to exhibit as many of the entries as possible, we need to fund this festival to bring in - 

  • Jurors to judge the movies - $2,000 in travel and payment
  • Venues - $1,000 - $2,000 in venue rental
  • Promotional materials - T-Shirts, Buttons, and Posters - $1,000 - $2,000
  • Future festivals - $2,000

This Festival Will Impact the Artists of the Future

TUFF was designed to expose students to work not otherwise seen in the cinema at-large while giving emerging artists a venue in a location known for its beauty as well as its patronage of the arts. 

Funds

Sierra Nevada College has provided a small grant for the festival, but, like all festivals, we need more to solidify the festival for this year and, more importantly, years to come. The ultimate goal for TUFF is a regional destination festival showcasing contemporary, boundary expanding work. We have a great in-class team, as well as experienced faculty advisers with a few festivals under their belts and a wealth of experience as artists and academics. We also already have a world-wide network of makers ready and willing to share work with the festival. All that is missing is you.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help the festival by sharing this campaign, volunteering for events as they come up, and commenting below. TUFF is already a global operation. Contribute today, in any and every way you can.

story:
THE MISSION: SEND DENISE TO VEGAS

In 2016, Denise won “Best-in-Show” in the Las Vegas International Juried Art Competition at Jana’s RedRoom Gallery, located in Las Vegas, Nevada. The winning artwork, “The Jacks of Jupiter”was a 40 x 26 work-on-paper from her House of Cards Series, which reimagines in 56 large-scale works-on-paper -- clubs become trees, spades reference bones and fossils, diamonds transform in to constellations and celestial bodies, and hearts draw inspiration from Egyptian Tomb paintings and the Tarot.

This year she is returning with a selection of 12 of these large-scale works for a one-person show and you can help send her share her work with a new audience in Vegas!

THE PROBLEM: FRAMES ARE EXPENSIVE

Currently Denise has five pieces professionally framed and needs to frame 7 more.  At $150 each, she could really use your help.

Here's one of the "cards" beautifully framed now hanging at Jana's Redroom!

 

HOW CAN YOU HELP

Purchase art, products, or help provide transportation and lodging. Anything small or large is appreciated!

THE VENUE

Jana’s RedRoom is a working art studio and gallery. Their goal is to inspire the next generation of art collectors by offering original works at reasonable prices. Jana’s RedRoom got its start inside in the world famous Arts Factory in July of 2012.

Millions of people come to Las Vegas every year, Jana Lynch, owner of the RedRoom, is always coming up with new and creative ideas to get people out of the casinos and into the world of emerging artists. As winner of the their first international juried exhibition, Denise is looking forward to this one-person show in August and deepening the connection the wonderful the artists and collectors of Las Vegas that she met last year.

story:
Denise Levertov Plaque

Denise Levertov is one of the most accomplished poets ever to call Seattle home. She lived here for the last 8 years of her life and also was on the faculty of one of the Cascadia bioregion's most legendary poetry events, the 1963 Vancouver Poetry Conference. A huge body of work, poetry AND essays, some of which on poetics have been critical to post-WWII North American poetry, her correspondence with poets like William Carlos Williams and Robert Duncan, her brilliant teaching at Stanford and other institutions and her fierce anti-war stance are all part of why she deserves this recognition nearly 20 years after her death. Her poems about Mt. Rainier may be the best ever done of The Mountain, as we say here in Seattle. And people walk by the house she lived in for eight years with no idea of the brilliance that went on inside.

SPLAB is teaming up with the Rainier Valley Rotary to have a plaque created and installed and we need your support to ensure it happens.

  • The plaque will be unveiled as part of the 4th Cascadia Poetry Festival, Nov 3-6, 2016 at Spring Street Center in Seattle: www.CascadiaPoetryFestival.org
  • The festival this year honors the memory and legacy of Levertov with readings, a panel discussion and a ritual walk to Levertov's grave.
  • All contributors will be recognized in the festival program.
  • Contributors of more than $35 will get an all-access Gold Pass for entry into all this year's festival events.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please help by:

  • Getting the word out about this campaign and festival.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Consider attending the festival and the ritual walk to her grave.
  • Subscribe to the blog at www.splab.org for information on this project and other poetry/bioregional news out of Cascadia.

story:
Martrys of Humboldt 7

In 1998, an international team of artists (Janet Pavone, Daniel Hopewell & Cecilia Herrero) traveled to Havana by invitation from a Cuban conservation group of architects and planners to paint a mural about the history of the neighborhood inside the 'Martrys of Humboldt 7' public school.

The school is located in the Cayo Hueso district of Havana, home of the now famous 'Callejon de Hamel'.

Twenty years later, the mural requires restoration, in order to protect the history it portrays and as a cultural amenity in the school and neighborhood.

There is no public or private funding available for a project like this, which is why we are asking for your help.

We need only $5000 USD to buy equipment and paint and to secure paint, equipment and subsistence for the artists, including young muralists from Nicaragua who will travel to Cuba to help with the restoration. None of the artists will profit from this project. All money raised will be used directly to restore the mural.

Why?

The Cuban people have been under an economic blockade for over 50 years and the difficulties this presents for the school system means there are very limited funds for projects like this. Art and culture are fundamental to telling the story of the Cuban people and their revolution, and this public school finds itself at the centre of an artistic renaissance in Havana. Outside the school gates, tourists flood 'Callejon de Hamel' to see the murals, music and dancing. Inside the school, the children need to feel that the mural that celebrates their history and the area is also preserved and looked after. This is what this project is about.

If you can't give, then shout!

Please share with your friends, family and colleagues - as widely as you can!

En Español

En resumen, amigos, estamos recaudando fonods para restorar este mural, pintado en 1998, en la escuela Martires del Humboldt 7, en La Habana, Cuba. El mural sigue ahi, pero necesita restauracion. El mural cuenta la historia del barrio y de las acciones de los estudiantes universitarios en la lucha contra Batista en los años 50. Por favor contribuyan lo que puedan y compártenlo con tod@s!

story:
Hello There! My name is Aaron Decker, a jeweler based in Michigan. My day job is in product development with Shinola Detroit, while I also maintain a thriving studio jewelry practice. I grew up in Maine around my grandfather who was a clocksmith, I studied jewelry as a way to connect with his memory upon his passing. He always taught me that good work requires good tools. 

The past ten years Ive developed my practice, received degrees in metalsmithing from Cranbrook Academy of Art, and Maine College of Art, and won numerous awards. I really derive all my energy from what I learned when I was around my grandfather, a true craftsmen. 

In this segment of my career, I have taken on several large jobs such as making bowls for the Shinola Hotel, Contributing a jewelry ling to the brand as well. Participating in several exhibitions nationally and internationally - all while having a basement studio and a hand me down kiln from the 1970's :) You make it work when you have too. 

With this growth I am looking to expand my tools, and update them. A new Kiln for enameling, the process I am exploring in my practice, and a ventilation system to make my studio safe for me and my continued practice. Both tools are paramount for my progression and I'm excited to ask for your participation in making it happen. I hope to raise $1300 for this endeavor.

PERKS!!!!!!!

The tools im specifically looking to purchase are a larger kiln from Rio, model 1000, which runs $950, and an HAKKO Fume Extraction System that costs $795. 

The Perks vary depending on how much you're able to donate. While everyone who donates will receive something, those who donate between $100-$300 dollars will received exceptional pieces of one of a kind jewelry and objects including Enameled Wall Dots, Enameled bowls, a beaded Enamel Necklace or pair of earrings! All funds will go to buying the new tools, and making the splendid gifts for all those who donated!

Achieving this goal is important in my studio practice, and the impact of it will be huge as I take on new projects in the coming years and begin to build new bodies of work, and enamel jewelry. 

While I know not all are able to contribute I would very much appreciate you sharing this funding campaign in your social circles and to all those who are interested. I appreciate any and all contributions you are willing to give.  Please use Indiegogo share tools and your online social media platforms to share :)

 

Warmly,

 

Aaron Decker
story_txt:
Hello There! My name is Aaron Decker, a jeweler based in Michigan. My day job is in product development with Shinola Detroit, while I also maintain a thriving studio jewelry practice. I grew up in Maine around my grandfather who was a clocksmith, I studied jewelry as a way to connect with his memory upon his passing. He always taught me that good work requires good tools. 
The past ten years Ive developed my practice, received degrees in metalsmithing from Cranbrook Academy of Art, and Maine College of Art, and won numerous awards. I really derive all my energy from what I learned when I was around my grandfather, a true craftsmen. 
In this segment of my career, I have taken on several large jobs such as making bowls for the Shinola Hotel, Contributing a jewelry ling to the brand as well. Participating in several exhibitions nationally and internationally - all while having a basement studio and a hand me down kiln from the 1970's :) You make it work when you have too. 
With this growth I am looking to expand my tools, and update them. A new Kiln for enameling, the process I am exploring in my practice, and a ventilation system to make my studio safe for me and my continued practice. Both tools are paramount for my progression and I'm excited to ask for your participation in making it happen. I hope to raise $1300 for this endeavor.

PERKS!!!!!!!
The tools im specifically looking to purchase are a larger kiln from Rio, model 1000, which runs $950, and an HAKKO Fume Extraction System that costs $795. 
The Perks vary depending on how much you're able to donate. While everyone who donates will receive something, those who donate between $100-$300 dollars will received exceptional pieces of one of a kind jewelry and objects including Enameled Wall Dots, Enameled bowls, a beaded Enamel Necklace or pair of earrings! All funds will go to buying the new tools, and making the splendid gifts for all those who donated!
Achieving this goal is important in my studio practice, and the impact of it will be huge as I take on new projects in the coming years and begin to build new bodies of work, and enamel jewelry. 
While I know not all are able to contribute I would very much appreciate you sharing this funding campaign in your social circles and to all those who are interested. I appreciate any and all contributions you are willing to give.  Please use Indiegogo share tools and your online social media platforms to share :)
 
Warmly,
 
Aaron Decker

story:
Introduction of Ekoin

Nice to meet you!

We are Koya-san Shingon Sect, Jyun Bekkaku Honzan (Semi-Special Head Temple), Ekoin.

Thank you very much for visiting this page out of many campaigns.

Ekoin is a Buddhist Temple with a history of 1200 years, located in one of the world heritages, Mt. Koya, Wakayama, Japan.

It is called the Ekoin (回向院 in Japanese character) because the Master Kukai (a.k.a. Kobo-Daishi who is a founder of Shingon Sect) erected a five-storied pagoda in this location, and his disciple Dosho, the priest, performed Eko (回向 in Japanese), the revolving of the people (the memorial service of the ancestors) in here. 

During Hoei period (early 1700s), Ekoin is renamed to our current name by Yoshimune Tokugawa who is 8th shogun of Tokugawa Shogunate. (The name given at that time had same sound, but different character as 恵光院 )

We have two halls. Main hall enshrines Amida Nyorai (Amitabha in Sanskrit), Kukai (Kobo-Daishi), and Fudo Myo (Acalanatha in Sanskrit). And the other hall called Bishamon Hall enshrines Bishamon Ten (Vaisravana in Sanskrit) as its principal images.

Ekoin is also known as a Shukubo (宿坊 in Japanese).

Shukubo is a place where you can get the taste of monk's life style with Temple Lodging. You can stay in our temple, enjoy our Shojin Ryori (Buddhist Vegetarian Cuisine) and experience activities.

A specialty experiences at Ekoin areÂ "Homa Fire Ritual" and "Meditation". Visitors can join the Homa Fire Ritual, performed every morning with monks. And various kinds of meditation programs are offered.

 

 

Introduction of Koya-san

Koya-san (Mt. Koya) is well known as a Headquarter of Shingon Sect Buddhism which is found by Master Kukai (Kobo-Daishi) back in 9th century. It is also known as a World Heritage certified in 2004. Therefore, Koya-san is not only a place for religious believers, but also an unique place for visitors & travelers now. Within Koya-san, there is the Master Head Temple, Kongobuji in the middle, and many of Head and Semi Head Temples around. Each temple has its own historical episodes and heritages. Every time you visit, you must find and experience something different.

 

Current Situtaion in Koya-san

Due to COVID-19 situation, visitors to Koya-san has dramatically decreased. The number of visitors to Ekoin now is 5% of usual. If this situation continues, we will face the difficulty to preserve this historically & religiously important heritages. Your contribution will save it.

 

 

Why we started this project & What we want to do

Under the COVID-19 situation, people all over the world are asked self-restraint (or maybe stricter in some places) to go out. Of course, going abroad is out of question now. People cannot come and pray in  Koya-san even if they wanted to. We understand this is a necessary sacrifice.

Under such a situation, we monks at Ekoin discussed,

 

What can we do for the world?

What can we do for Koya-san? 

How can we help the world?

How can we preserve the history, culture, heritage, and people in here?

 

And we reached an answer,

 

What we monks can do is praying for the world from here.

This is our motivation to start this campaign.

 

 

What you'll get from contribution

-We will pray "World Peace" and "World Health" instead of backers.

-Backers will receive unique return items depend on the amount of contribution. All items will be prayed by monks in Ekoin with certain traditional praying ceremony. Please check out the all perks we offer.

-Through your contribution, you can save not only temple itself, but people's life working for Koya-san temples such as craftsman in here, cooks in here etc.

 

Finally

Thank you for reading to the end.

Ekoin sincerely pray that the coronavirus pandemic will end as soon as possible and everyone will be able to visit Koya-san.

Until people come to a peaceful world without any conflicts, we monks offer prayers. So that you can relieve the suffering of living things.  Gassho (合掌)

 

This project will be implemented in the flexible funding. Even the total contributions are less than target amount we set, we will perform all perks to the backers.

story:
Project Summary

Hi!

I'm Jennifer Taylor, I'm a self-taught artist and this is my newly acquired abandoned house and side lot in Gary, IN.

It's startling and deeply sad to see so many homes around here simply collapse after being abandoned.  I can't imagine how painful it must have been for families to realize that, for a variety of reasons, they could no longer stay in their homes and the only solution was to simply walk away.

This is one of those houses and it's been calling to me.  I want to revive it - not only to its former self - but to a place of glory!

After its many years of neglect, I'm going to celebrate its existence and exterior with SPARKLES and give it purpose by turning part of it into a community artist studio for classes and artist residencies.

The side lot will become a sculpture garden where artists will be invited to come make sculpture and gardeners to plant flowers and vegetables.

My intention is simply to do something fun while also enabling this little SPARKLE HOUSE to  'spark change' in this Gary, IN community.

As you can see from the video, it will need quite a bit of work.  I've saved and borrowed but still could use a little help.  If you can spare a few dollars I'd be grateful.  If not, no worries but please stay tuned to the renovation progress and, when it's finished, stop by for a visit!

What will the money be used for?

$2000    Exterior House Prep and Paint

$   900   Special Sparkles/Glue/Sealer

$2000    Sculpture Garden slabs for sculpture support/mulch

$4500    ADA wheelchair ramp/accessible bathroom

$1200     Canvas/Paint/Brushes/Stools

$2000     Adaptable Classroom Lighting

$2400      Front stairs/outdoor classroom painting deck

$2300       Exterior Lighting

$2000      Four Dumpsters/Permits

The Impact

Sometimes in life we just have to do something fun!  In an area that's depressed like Gary, IN, your donation becomes part of lifting spirits and inspiring hopeful action toward change.  Your donation - large or small - is really important and also becomes part of the fun!

Challenges

It took eight months to persuade the city of Gary to finally allow me to purchase this house. I know it won't be an easy project but I'm super-excited and determined to see it thru! 

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you aren't able to donate at this time but it would be equally helpful if you could share this Indiegogo Campaign with your friends.

  • Indiegogo makes it easy with their sharing tools!

story:
About My Practice and the Dream House Trailer Project

I am an artist living and working in Tulsa, Oklahoma. I have an interdisciplinary approach to my practice in both materials and presentation, which provides an overall structure to my work, as does my personal narrative in/out of social context; the materiality of objects; repetition and scale; and space/place. I have mounted several installation works over the last ten years. (Secretly), I also have a career as a luchador wrestler, which counts as performance experience (even though it was all totally real!). I am currently working on my thesis in the MFA Art Practice program at the School of Visual Arts in New York City and will graduate in Summer 2019. I received a BFA in Graphic Design from the University of Tulsa.

To view examples of my work, visit my Instagram: @nic_finley

"The Dream House Trailer Experience" is near and dear to my heart, as it is semi-autobiographical. I grew up in a trailer park and have both fond feelings of living there and the feelings my parents experienced - embarrassment, not achieving the American Dream and the stigma of being labeled "Trailer Trash." The Dream House Trailer gives a glimpse into trailer life, but also turns the story around on the 1% and Barbie falling on hard times - with a lot of humor, of course. This year, Satellite Art Show artists will exhibit in individual storage containers, so the venue is perfect to depict a trailer. Because this is a new work, I have no images, but I can tell you that the container will become a trailer and I will become Trailer Park Barbie! 

Exhibiting at the Satellite Art Show will be the biggest show of my art career to date, while also providing invaluable experience and a very large audience to view my work. Your support will be part of an important phase in my art practice and will give me the encouragement to continue experimenting with work like the Dream House Trailer. Thank you in advance for teaming up with me to make this happen!

The Breakdown...and Donor Perks!

"The Dream House Trailer Experience" is a new work and will premiere at the Satellite Art Show! With that, all costs related to materials, design and set-up will be incurred to make this happen. Here is a breakdown of expenses:

• Satellite Art Show booth fee (20' storage container): $2200

• Artwork materials/production costs (vinyl printing; props for "house"/performance) : $2000

• Travel (roundtrip airfare Tulsa to Miami, luggage fees): $400

TOTAL: $4600

If you have any questions about the expenses, please let me know and I will be happy to provide answers.

PERKS! (Images coming soon in the Updates section)

$25 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket)!

$50 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket), PLUS an Official Dream House Trailer postcard autographed by Trailer Park Barbie!

$75 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket); an Official Dream House Trailer postcard autographed by Trailer Park Barbie; PLUS, an Exclusive digital photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show!

$100 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket); an Official Dream House Trailer postcard autographed by Trailer Park Barbie; an Exclusive digital photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show; PLUS, a Special shout-out on Instagram by Trailer Park Barbie during Satellite Art Show!

$150 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket); an Official Dream House Trailer postcard autographed by Trailer Park Barbie; an Exclusive digital photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show; a Special shout-out on Instagram by Trailer Park Barbie during Satellite Art Show; PLUS, an Autographed 8x10 photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show!

$250 or more: Set of three (3) Limited Edition Dream House Trailer buttons (the kind you pin on your shirt or jacket); an Official Dream House Trailer postcard autographed by Trailer Park Barbie; an Exclusive digital photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show; a Special shout-out on Instagram by Trailer Park Barbie during Satellite Art Show; an Autographed 8x10 photograph of the Dream House Trailer and Trailer Park Barbie at Satellite Art Show; PLUS, a Numbered print designed by the artist commemorating the premiere of Dream House Trailer!

No Money. No Problem!

Thank you for taking the time to get to know me, my art practice and Dream House Trailer for the Satellite Art Show; that is a form of support too! If you have a few more minutes to spare and could share my campaign on social media or shoot a few emails to friends, that would be amazing. Time is valuable too and I appreciate you spending it on me :)

To spread the word on my campaign:

• Click on the "Share this Campaign" link at the top of the page and several social media options will appear. 

• Copy and paste this link for emails to friends: https://igg.me/at/dreamhouse-trailer

story:
I am currently working on the design and development of a stunning collection of sho-art shoes, shoes that are artwork / conceptual design.

Each shoe is hand-made, and it has created unique art.

The new collection is called a "playground" (a temporary name) and deals with movement, balance and playfulness.

The idea is that the shoes will be presented to the general public in museums / galleries just like the creation of art.

Only with your help can I fulfill my vision and dream.

Thanks!

story:
Share skills, co-create art, receive free bike!

We, a group of burners from Lithuania, would like to   d o n a t e  200+ decorated  b i k e s  collected in the aftermath of  B u r n i n g   M a n  to our local communities in order to cheer them up and make a difference in our society! We will remix, recreate and sometimes reinvent the bicycles — and finish it all off with an  A r t B i k e  P a r a d e  which will ignite and positively impact, come join the fun!

 

 

This is the not the first time we're doing it, either (last years page)! We learned some tough lessons, but also saw some meaningful impact, and everyone loved it. The project is simultaneously a spiritual successor for the Who Did That to My Bike? annual bike parade in Vilnius which was taking place since 2013!

 

 

The almost three hundred bicycles come from the ones left over after the Burning Man arts festival in Nevada, USA. We are helping Burning Man as well - by meaningfully repurposing the bikes that were lost or discarded by attendees.

 

 

 

 

The workshop is going to take place this summer in the territory of an Art Incubator on a beautiful location near lake Mastis in the small city of Telšiai. Starting on June 4 - Jun. 17 students and teachers from all over Lithuania will be joined by makers and creators from all over the world to fix, weld, tinker, illuminate, program and decorate. Participants will recreate the bikes artistically, gain all sorts of skills while doing so - and take the finished art bikes home as their own!

 

 

 

What are the costs:

We estimated that approximately $12,000 would cover the following for the Art Bike Invasion in Lithuania:

  • $4,000 art bike workshop materials, tools, equipment etc. (thank you Lithuanian Cultural Foundation/Lietuvos Kultūros fondas for giving us a Grant for that!).
  • $3000 food and basic living costs for volunteers - the project is run on 100% volunteer efforts and we have a very nice international team coming and need to feed them! (and thank you US Embassy in Lithuania for giving us a Grant for that!).
  • $500 fundraiser banking fees, parade organisation and promotion  expenses .​
  • $1,500 shipment of the partial load of 40ft container loaded with art bikes from the U.S. to Lithuania
  • $2,000 logistic and other expenses such as transportation of the container from the Black Rock desert (Nevada) to the port in L.A.
  • $1,000 storage of the container at Klaipėda port (Lithuania), customs procedures and local logistics to the storage in Telšiai.

As we have been loading the bikes and driving the truck to L.A.the  logistics drills down to approximately $30 per bicycle - and through this fundraiser, we are trying to cover the logistics costs, as everything else has just been covered!!!

To find out more, enrol as a volunteer and follow our progress - go to our website or even follow us on good old Facebook.

Did we mention there's an Art Bike Parade at the end??

 

Help spread the word!

♥
story_txt:
Share skills, co-create art, receive free bike!We, a group of burners from Lithuania, would like to   d o n a t e  200+ decorated  b i k e s  collected in the aftermath of  B u r n i n g   M a n  to our local communities in order to cheer them up and make a difference in our society! We will remix, recreate and sometimes reinvent the bicycles — and finish it all off with an  A r t B i k e  P a r a d e  which will ignite and positively impact, come join the fun!  This is the not the first time we're doing it, either (last years page)! We learned some tough lessons, but also saw some meaningful impact, and everyone loved it. The project is simultaneously a spiritual successor for the Who Did That to My Bike? annual bike parade in Vilnius which was taking place since 2013!  The almost three hundred bicycles come from the ones left over after the Burning Man arts festival in Nevada, USA. We are helping Burning Man as well - by meaningfully repurposing the bikes that were lost or discarded by attendees.    The workshop is going to take place this summer in the territory of an Art Incubator on a beautiful location near lake Mastis in the small city of Telšiai. Starting on June 4 - Jun. 17 students and teachers from all over Lithuania will be joined by makers and creators from all over the world to fix, weld, tinker, illuminate, program and decorate. Participants will recreate the bikes artistically, gain all sorts of skills while doing so - and take the finished art bikes home as their own!   What are the costs:We estimated that approximately $12,000 would cover the following for the Art Bike Invasion in Lithuania:
$4,000 art bike workshop materials, tools, equipment etc. (thank you Lithuanian Cultural Foundation/Lietuvos Kultūros fondas for giving us a Grant for that!).

$3000 food and basic living costs for volunteers - the project is run on 100% volunteer efforts and we have a very nice international team coming and need to feed them! (and thank you US Embassy in Lithuania for giving us a Grant for that!).

$500 fundraiser banking fees, parade organisation and promotion  expenses .​
$1,500 shipment of the partial load of 40ft container loaded with art bikes from the U.S. to Lithuania
$2,000 logistic and other expenses such as transportation of the container from the Black Rock desert (Nevada) to the port in L.A.
$1,000 storage of the container at Klaipėda port (Lithuania), customs procedures and local logistics to the storage in Telšiai.
As we have been loading the bikes and driving the truck to L.A.the  logistics drills down to approximately $30 per bicycle - and through this fundraiser, we are trying to cover the logistics costs, as everything else has just been covered!!!To find out more, enrol as a volunteer and follow our progress - go to our website or even follow us on good old Facebook.Did we mention there's an Art Bike Parade at the end??

 
Help spread the word!♥

story:
* A big thanks to our backers for the amount raised with this campaign!

A relaunch is availiable so that we can reach our base goal! You can find it here!

 

Requiem for Greece is a community of Live Action Role Playing Games enthusiasts, created at February 2014. Right now, it numbers more than 70 active players in three major cities in Greece: Athens, Thessaloniki and Heraklion and a Storytelling team of 12.

Our chronicle is based on Vampire: The Requiem (Second Edition) by Onyxpath Publishing and counts over a hundred local live sessions and 8 countrywide gatherings that we like to call Grand Elysiums. It is a political horror game, taking place in an alternative and darker version of our world in the southern country of the Balkan peninsula, Greece.

These larger in scale, cross-city Events are the soul of our community. The backstory for these is created by the ongoing story of our Chronicle.

Players meet in one of the 3 cities to portray their characters and maneuver through the political scene of the dark creatures that are the focus of the story. These events are the best way for our community to get closer and also to connect the dots of the intercity plots.

The 9th Grand Elysium will take place  in Thessaloniki (Greece) during the 8th and 9th of December 2018. It will offer around 6 hours of gameplay each day.

The location that has been chosen for the event is an old Jewish inn called Bensousan Han ("han" in Turkish language means motel or inn) from the Ottoman Era. More info about the building and its history you can find in the links at the end of the description.

Through this campaign we plan to fund the base costs of the event that include the following:

            

Even though the base goal will offer every participant a great LARP experience, we will be able to augment the event with some additions if we reach the following stretch goals.

With a stretch goal of 1200 euros we will be able to rent additional space of the venue and pay for additional performers and props for the event!

With a stretch goal of 1600 Euros the event will be filmed and a documentation video will be available online!

Further stretch goals will be announced in the future.

 

Players of "Requiem For Greece" will get another chance to participate in a cross-city event that will change the in-game story forever.

Guests will get the chance to leave their daily routine behind for a few hours and be invited to a special Gala. With our help and instructions, they will portray mortal characters and will have the opportunity to interact with the various creatures of our Chronicle.  How immersive this interaction is going to be depends on them and the perk they choose. And if you think  that by playing a mortal you are useless... Chronicles of Darkness are here to teach us otherwise.

As for the Souvenirs included in the Perks... you can take a glimpse at the photos below. 

* Τhe Elixir in the picture is just a sample. The one you will get may look different as its handmade. ** The Dicebag does NOT include dice. You will have to use your own ^^

Even if you cant' participate, you have the chance to support our  community and make LARP experience more accessible in Greece.

Requiem for Greece is a team of LARP enthusiasts that focus on running a fun and immersive game. None of the members earns any income from this activity.

If money contribution is a complication for you, the event offers other opportunities for you to help.

For example, the event will be open for amateur photographers, musicians, and artists of any kind to show their work and enhance the experience for everyone else.

If you can think of any other way of helping, feel free to contacts us. Same goes in case you need more info about Requiem For Greece or Live action Role-playing generally.

Don’t forget to spread the word by using the Indiegogo sharing tools.

 

Requiem for Greece (Facebook)
Requiem for Greece (Website)
Bensousan Han (Facebook)

Contact info:
info@kindred.gr

story:
I have been experimenting with new technologies to create artwork since the 1970s. I have acquired many new skills that weren't even available when I attended school, and the capabilities keep advancing.

With as little as $5,000 I could print and frame a number of large works along with multiple smaller pieces, and I would be able to show them in a gallery setting. These prints would be made on the best printers available, with archival inks on fine art paper. The matted prints will, finally, be framed under plexiglass. They will be museum quality works. I have been busy creating new works, everyday, on the computer - I just need to turn them into real Objects of Art. With these new works in hand I could approach galleries and gain representation, as well as participate in group shows across the country. 

My work is very unique, and the larger size will really make them stand out as powerful visual statements. The colors will be so vibrant that these prints will almost seem to reach out and grab the viewer! It would make for a very exciting exhibition.

Any money I receive will be used to create the prints. A single print will cost $125, plus shipping. To mat and frame a print this size will cost around $200. I will do as much of the assembly of the framing as possible. I am thoroughly dedicated to doing this.

story:
WHO ARE WE? ​

East Street Arts are a creative social enterprise and registered charity based in Leeds, UK. We create space for making art, social events and learning opportunities to make our cities better places to live and work.

Our work can be seen on buildings, the high street and in neighbourhoods. We are here to support artists as we believe they have the talent, energy, ideas and determination to change our worlds.
 

A LITTLE BIT OF CONTEXT

We have always dreamed of having our very own hostel. Inspired by the accommodation we’ve encountered on our travels, we saw a real opportunity to open something similar in Leeds. We wanted to provide affordable accommodation which was designed, created and run by artists, for curious travellers.

And we did it!

In 2016, we opened a temporary pop-up Art Hostel on Kirkgate in Leeds. The first social enterprise of its kind in the UK, the hostel provided a portal directly into the underbelly of the city’s creative and independent scene.

And it was great!

10,170 guests from 117 countries, eight unique rooms, 18,282 cups of tea, 424 litres of paint later...we found out that we had to close the temporary hostel earlier than we'd planned after we lost the building we were leasing.

We were gutted!

But, we’d proven that the Art Hostel could be everything we’d dreamed of (and more)! And we just couldn’t let it all end there…
 

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?

So, we found the perfect building for a permanent Art Hostel and made the decision to take out a loan to secure it. A risky but essential move.

But a building does not an Art Hostel make.

We now need to inject the art...and we need your help to do it!

It is the art that makes the Art Hostel so very special. Its vibrant and varied rooms provide the exciting and unique experience that our guests have come to know and love.

We desperately need to raise the funds to commission artists who will transform the space. Without your help, we simply won’t be able to do it!

The Art Hostel isn't just a place to stay. It's a home for volunteers from around the world, a place to make and show work, call in for a Tuesday tea or take part in Pay-As-You-Feel yoga. It's a place for you. Which is why we need your support!
 

WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?

All of the money raised will go straight to paying artists and funding materials to create a selection of fantastic Art Hostel rooms and communal spaces.
 

HOW MUCH DO WE NEED TO RAISE?

A grand total of £15,000 

(Don't worry if the currency appears as USD, the campaign is in GBP. You can change the currency you view the campaign in on the bottom left corner of your page.)
 

WHAT’S IN IT FOR YOU?

Obviously, you’ll get the warm glow of being a generous human being, but we also have a selection of awesome rewards available to give you another little incentive too.
 

WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO NEXT?

Make your pledge!

All of the money you give will go towards paying artists and providing materials to transform the hostel rooms.

We know that not everyone is in a position to donate, so please help us by spreading the word.
 

WHAT ELSE DO YOU NEED TO KNOW?

The Art Hostel is a social enterprise run by registered charity, East Street Arts, so helping the project immediately proves that you’re ultimately a very good person. Expect good karma! You’ll allow something truly special to be created within, and for Leeds, and those who visit the city.


Find out more about Art Hostel and East Street Arts here:
www.arthostel.org.uk and www.eaststreetarts.org.uk
Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ

story:
Ride the Synth Wave!

Sylvain Niles and the NEON VICE Crew consists of veteran inclusive minded burners and volunteers from several camps and projects whose exploits range across past art cars, large Playa installations, and coordinated Burning Man related events.

The NEON VICE Art Car intends to manifest the styles and nostalgia of the retro futuristic 80's themes embodied by synthwave and vaporwave aesthetics, while bringing grade A Karaoke, a full interior lounge, state of the art turn of the century integrated projection technology, a radical sound system, and a community of friends excited to share all of this with you!

This project will help us bring the much larger than life iconic Countach style to the playa, serving as a beacon for all night riders and a nostalgic roaming home on the playa.  The exterior is a canvas for projectors, allowing projection mapped patterns to be displayed on the exterior between LED lighting strips. The retro futuristic interior style NEON VICE brings also gives a unique and uncommon flavor to interactions and sharing in the desert, with soft neon lighting, vinyl flooring, planters, UV lights, couches, and a bar on the interior lounge to set the mood.

 

And we have some unique rewards to give back to our patrons!  Have a look! >>>

 

How your donation helps us & what you can get

We have put together some solid plans to ensure we bring this vehicle to that thing in the desert, and the more help we get, the better this project will be!  We have already acquired the Bus, Pro Sound System, Safety systems, and Steel, and are now looking to finish the build and visual aspects with the LED System, Final Construction/Fabrication costs, and projection systems.

For our final stretch, we are looking to raise $3000 minimum to cover our MVMV (minimum viable mutant vehicle), and up to $8000 to cover our final version!  This amount covers:

  • $3000 Final Construction Fabrication Supplies 
    • Exterior skin, 
    • Interior fabric/materials, 
    • Paint sealant 
    • Brackets, Bolts and other misc. materials
    • Electronics and Wiring Infrastructure
  • $1000 LED System 
    • LED strips/lights for interior and Exterior
    • LED power infrastructure
    • Over a Kilometer of custom wiring harness
    • Distributed microcontroller network
  • $4000 Projection
    • Internal projector
    • External Projectors
    • PC/GPU/Software for Mapping
    • Power system and cooling

We have some amazing and radical perk packs for the various donation levels including:

  • Neon Vice Stickers for your trapper-keeper
  • Custom Enamel Pins and Patches for your jean jacket
  • Tours of the build site and the opportunity to have your name immortalized on the vehicle
  • Even on location parties thrown in the vehicle for you and your crew!

If we make each of the above goals, we will be adding additional rewards!

  • If we meet our first goal of $3000, we will be throwing a special party at the burn, if you donated we will send you the location just before Burning Man gate opens in a special email to our patrons!
  • If we meet our second goal of a total of $4000 we will be designing and reward a new special sticker design to all our backers!
  • If we get close to our third goal of $8000 total, well, I think that will be a surprise for now, but we'll reveal it if we get closer!  It's a doozy!

Now we really need your help to get this vehicle running smooth like a Betamax, but if we can’t meet our goal, we plan to prioritize accordingly to bring the best offering we can.

Funds donated will cover:

  • First, the minimum build requirements to finish the vehicle from the construction and fabrication costs.
  • Second, the minimum lighting to make the vehicle visible and engaging.
  • Third, the remainder will help bring the vehicle as close to design as possible visually, ensuring that we bring the best NEON VICE we can to the playa to share!

 

The Impact

The 80’s Synthwave style let’s us all merge together a love of the 80’s styles with our love of all things futuristic (or retro-futuristic) creating a feeling that is both heavily nostalgic and brightly modern!

Your contribution will help us share this rolling experience with as many people as possible, at Burning Man and beyond.   We plan to help grow the community around the art car crew in the Seattle area and further as we share in this achievement.  

Our crew combined has completed, built, and created many related past projects including but not limited to: 2 art cars, 8+ theme camps at regional and main burn events, more than 7 on playa installations in camps and on open playa, regional and on playa events, volunteers to regional and main burn roles and many more art and experiential collaborations!

We can’t wait to share NEON VICE with you, and appreciate any level of contribution.  We are running this HIGH PRESSURE LAST MINUTE FUNDRAISER to get our final push done, and we really need your help!


Risks & Challenges

We know there are risks, and being veterans burners, builders and artists with decades of experience has helped prepare us for eventualities.  Many of us are leveraging beyond senior level professional planning and project management experience in addition to professional creatives to help collaborate on the best plan A, B, and C to bring this project to fruition.

Our strategy involves increasing levels of MVMV (minimum viable mutant vehicle) and the ability to leverage backup systems and plans to combat eventualities.  By prioritizing what it takes to deliver on our promises we can react quickly to problem solve or establish creative solutions to address any gaps.

As a team we have run through a number of past experienced challenges and incorporated these into the project plans so we are all clear on each fallback plan.


Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t worry if you aren’t able to contribute directly, we still need any help you can provide!

  • Share this Indeigogo campaign as much as you are willing!  Let others know what we are doing!
  • Visit our pages and give a like/follow/share on Facebook or Instagram(@neonviceartcar)!
  • Invite others to our events and to visit us on playa!  We look forward to seeing all of you and sharing in the experience!

See you in the dust!

story:
Who we are

Hello! We are a very diverse team of  Russians. Some of us work at a cinema, other fight forest fires. There are street artists and engineers; some even don’t bother working at all and live in a ceiling cabinet… What brings us together is our shared perception of the world, which has inspired us to create our artwork - Zarya.

We set big goals, some of them exceeding the length of human life. Perhaps that’s why our project was among the 70 winners of the Black Rock Honoraria Program this year. Their grant has helped us a lot and we built our carousel in Russia. Now it’s time to move on together so we will be grateful for your support!

What we do

Zarya (Aurora) - is a manually driven carousel, breathing out fire and smoke. The energy of the human motor magically transforms into creativity and joy overwhelming the people on the platform, making them feel sincere, free and light-hearted, travelling them back into the happy days of childhood.

The carousel looks rough and cinematic; it is covered by rust and stains, it is embroidered by charred woodwork and charming crack patterns. But all these do not frighten but cast a magic spell!

And when Zarya is set in motion and light and sounds are on – everything around fills up with irresistible vital energy, drive and euphoria. You can’t stop it unless you stop the spinning. But you actually don’t need this, as the platform moves at a reasonable speed and it is easy to keep the balance for the easy riders. Driving the carousel takes quite light physical inputs. When twisted, the installation flashes in clouds of smoke and shoots fire into the sky.

Why we need your money

We have assembled the carousel and it’s already travelling across the Atlantics on a ship, packed together with its charming beasts. They are sleeping calmly in the 27-feet container and we envy them as we can not afford this privilege until we find the remaining $12500 to make it all happen.

Two-way ticket to the blues

Bringing Zarya to Playa with the following withdrawal from Black Rock City costs $10000. We have already paid the first increment – $2000 for the naval freight - and $8000 is due. We can’t burn this object as there’s nothing to burn (mainly metal parts), nor can we abandon or sell it, as this is the only happy place in the word as we know it.

Gimme fuel, gimme fire, gimme that which I desire!

Our kid is quite insatiable. It drinks gasoline and breathes propane, so we will need 110 gallons of gas and 70 gallons of propane along with storage tanks. Also, Zarya can’t get by without electricity, which helps it glow, sound and emit smokes. The food for the carousel would cost $1500.

Smoke on the rotor...

Zarya boasts quite a post-apocalyptic appearance. Covered with smoke puffs, it looks like a celestial castle. Or, living by its name, a sundawn. Three smoke machines working together will make our carousel  stand on the soil of Playa and float in the sky above at the same time. Just try to imagine this!  Liquid smoke would take further $600.

...And fire in the sky

There is a 22-foot mast on the carousel. It spits out fire 6 feet above, making the fire tongue of Zarya. We will need to ensure its absolute safety for the Burning Man people. Hoses, valves, controllers, fire extinguishers and the like would  cost $1200.

So rock me mama like a wagon wheel

The carousel will need extra heavy-duty wheels. Concealed under the skirt of the carousel, these move it along the circle rail. These wheels are actually the whales carrying the world around the carousel. You do know what the sand of Playa is like, don't you? So for Zarya to survive the Burning Man, it would require spare wheels, at least six of them. Another $800.

Shine on you crazy diamond                        

Zarya consists of two principal parts. The carousel itself and the actuator assembly with the manual driving handle. So far, there has been an incredibly marvellous illumination of the main part of the caroussel, while the other section is bare. It should be lit with neon and lamps for eye appeal and safety. In our humble count it must be 400$.

What our project may bring to you

Join us in having fun around Zarya. Anyone is free to twist it.

In fact, Zarya can become what you want it to be. Musicians will be happy playing on a circle-shaped rotating stage with the sound of music reaching out all around. Dance lovers will catch their moment of glory on a steampunk-style dancing pylon. Kids will get just crazy riding the charming wooden beasts. Actors, poets, standup comedians will hijack ovations in the smoke and fire scenery. The overall euphoria in the surroundings will be spiced by the genuine lamp funk of the 60s and 70s, together with joy, drive and hugs.

Please, join us at the Burning Man 2019. Let's twist the carousel together!

Key concept

The main underlying idea of the project is post-apocalyptic utopia. The idea of a happy future. Zarya is the Russian name for aurora, or sun dawn. This is the beginning of a new chapter of life.The carousel represents a magic land which has somehow survived a global disaster. No boundaries exist here between fantasy and reality, childhood and maturity, instance and eternity. And it is where the happiness lives. There is no difference between givers and takers, between those who twist the carousel and those who ride it. They exist together as a whole.

Risks. Our plan in case we fail to raise the necessary amount

Dear friends. Most of us have never visited the Burning Man. So everything that is to happen will be just cool. We do have some experience in travel, expeditions and festivals, but this is going to be our first time of bringing our art to the Burning Man. We bet you know what we mean….))

If we dont raise the needed sum, we will just take our favorite perks - bottles, glasses, and a corkscrew - and will make our favorite The First Timer cocktail.

How else you can help

We will be very grateful if:

You are a blogger and you share a repost of our campaign

-you are a journalist and you make a catching story about us

-you are an art patron and you contact us directly

You know people who know people who know whom to let know so that everyone knows about our campaign

-you have a van or a car in California which you would like to share with us.

-you can give us a shelter in Los-Angeles from 10 to 17 July

- you have any other helpful ideas and let us know

Conclusion

When we learned about Zarya winning a grant from the BLACK ROCK HONORARIA PROGRAM we were very happy to gain recognition from the world's most renowned festival. Given that only one member if our team has visited the Burning Man, we are poised to face many difficulties. But we are ready to stand up to them! And we will twist our carousel together with you at the Burning Man 2019.

Please, join us on this endeavor.

Thank you for your support!
